items.title: TACT‚Äôs Partnership With Randstad is a ‚ÄòStep Forward‚Äô
items.snippet: TACT have partnered with Randstad to help young people in Manchester move from residential care into stable family environments. The post TACT‚Äôs Partnership With Randstad is a ‚ÄòStep Forward‚Äô appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
TACT’s Partnership With Randstad is a ‚ÄòStep Forward‚Äô

A new partnership between TACT Fostering and global talent leader Randstad aims to help young people in Greater Manchester move out of residential care and into stable, nurturing family homes.  

The Step Forward Scheme responds directly to urgent government calls to recruit more foster carers and reduce reliance on residential care, with Children and Families Minister Josh MacAlister warned that too many young people are entering residential care simply because there are not enough foster homes available.  

Supporting Young People Across Greater Manchester 

Many young people in residential care across Greater Manchester are ready to move into a family environment but cannot do so due to a lack of suitable foster carers. 

Step Forward offers a therapeutic, highly supported model designed to help these young people thrive within a family setting that is more suited to their needs. The pilot will work closely with local authorities across the region to identify young people who would benefit from this transition. 

Recruiting Local People with the Right Skills 

The partnership with Randstad aims to reach people across Greater Manchester who may be considering a career change, particularly those working in education, healthcare, youth work, policing, residential care, and social care. 

Alister Brown, Director of Strategic Partnerships and Service Development at TACT, said: ‚ÄúWorking with Randstad will help us reach people who may never have considered fostering. The government has been clear about the need to bring more families into fostering, and that‚Äôs exactly what we‚Äôre aiming to do. By using new recruitment approaches and offering strong support, we can open the door to people who previously felt fostering wasn‚Äôt viable for them.‚Äù

Richard Sutherland, Randstad Divisional Director, Social Work added: ‚ÄúThis is more than a career change; it’s a chance to use your expertise to build a stable future for a child who needs it most, backed by a leading charity and a financial package that truly respects your commitment.‚Äù 

Making Fostering a Realistic Career for Local Families 

Step Forward carers can earn up to ¬£54,860, often tax-free, including retainer payments and 28 days of planned breaks supported by a dedicated hub carer. With the cost of living continuing to affect households, TACT says it is essential to make fostering a financially sustainable option if we want more people to consider it. 

Alister Brown added: ‚ÄúPeople need reassurance that they can support their families while stepping into this role. Talking about the financial side of fostering can feel uncomfortable, but we have to make fostering viable for more people so that more children can live in nurturing family homes.‚Äù 

A Local Solution to a National Problem 

The government has been clear that the shortage of foster carers is pushing children into residential care unnecessarily. The Step Forward scheme in Greater Manchester aims to provide a local, practical solution, increasing the number of specialist foster carers and ensuring more young people can grow up in the family homes they deserve. 

Read more about Step Forward Fostering.

The post TACT’s Partnership With Randstad is a ‚ÄòStep Forward‚Äô appeared first on TACT.

items.title: TACT welcome Government Plans for 10,000 New Foster Carers
items.snippet: The government has revealed a major foster carer recruitment drive, with the aim of recruiting up to 10,000 new foster carers. The post TACT welcome Government Plans for 10,000 New Foster Carers appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
TACT welcome Government Plans for 10,000 New Foster Carers

TACT welcome Government Plans for 10,000 New Foster Carers.

Thousands more children in the social care system in England will grow up in loving and supportive homes, under government plans to recruit up to 10,000 new foster carers this parliament, giving more children the best possible start in life and opening up opportunity for every young person regardless of their background.  

A major recruitment drive, proposed by Government today, will tackle the critical shortage of foster carers in England, where approved carer numbers have fallen sharply, while the number of children in care has risen.  

This shortage means too many children are placed far from home or end up in residential care, where they often face struggles in school, health difficulties and even exploitation or exposure to criminal activity.  

The plans will be backed by ¬£88 million of funding to support foster carers and the network of frontline services that support them. It also means better support for existing foster carers, including clarity on the help available, assistance with home improvements, and access to peer support and advice through regional fostering hubs. 

Chief Executive, Andy Elvin, said: ‚ÄúWe welcome this news from Government today and are pleased that children, young people, and their foster families are at the centre of these proposals. Safely speeding up carer recruitment by removing unnecessary processes, improving retention by allowing decisions to be made in the foster home and overhauling the allegations process will all have a positive impact on children‚Äôs outcomes and foster carer numbers.

‚ÄúThe strong message from the Children‚Äôs Minister, Josh MacAlister, that all local authorities (LA‚Äôs) must merge their fostering and care services into Regional Care Co-ops (RCC‚Äôs) is equally welcome. The current system, where 152 LA‚Äôs are doing this separately, has not delivered a system that meets the needs of our children and young people. RCC‚Äôs will have the size and reach to fundamentally change the care system and it‚Äôs vital that Council leaders ensure their LAs are enthusiastically progressing this agenda.

‚ÄúStandalone RCC‚Äôs, set up as social enterprises owned by their constituent LA‚Äôs and working in partnership with likeminded independent fostering agencies can be the vehicle that delivers the extra foster homes we need.‚Äù

As the UK‚Äôs largest fostering agency, TACT already have initiatives and plans in place to allow more children and young people access to high quality, stable care, and that foster carers get the support they need. These include:

  • A new grant giving scheme, Making Spaces, which provides existing TACT foster carers with financial support to create extra space in their homes to continue fostering.
  • The recent acquisition of Foster Carer Values in North Wales, ensuring a bright not-for-profit future for the agency as Welsh Government moves towards removing profit-making from foster care by 2027.
  • The launch of an innovative Step Forward Fostering scheme to provide more foster families for children currently in residential care, using a proactive recruitment approach that targets skilled career‚Äëchangers and offers the specialist training, wraparound support, and financially sustainable fees that make fostering a viable new path for many more people.

Andy added: ‚ÄúWe look forward to working with the Department for Education and the emerging RCC‚Äôs, to deliver this ambitious agenda.‚Äù

The post TACT welcome Government Plans for 10,000 New Foster Carers appeared first on TACT.

items.title: Some people spend their lives quietly changing others‚Äô
items.snippet: Some people spend their lives quietly changing others‚Äô. Rachel is one of them. (Feed generated with FetchRSS)
items.content:
Some people spend their lives quietly changing others‚Äô. Rachel is one of them.

From teaching maths to supporting victims of trauma in the police, she has always been the person who shows up when someone needs her most. But it was a moment on duty‚Äîstanding beside an 18-month-old boy fighting for his life‚Äîthat changed her direction forever.

It made her ask: Who will care for him next?
That question eventually led her to fostering.

Today, Rachel is a single foster carer with Compass. The skills she gained in teaching and crisis support have become her superpowers: calming dysregulated children, trusting her instincts, understanding the pressures of school, adapting in the moment, and creating a safe, therapeutic home.

She says the support has been ‚Äúbrilliant,‚Äù and that fostering has brought some of the most meaningful moments of her life ‚Äî including the time her youngest son drew a picture of ‚Äúhis family‚Äù and added a respite child who had only arrived that week.

üí¨ ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a teacher, police officer or emergency worker‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre already equipped. Absolutely do it ‚Äì it‚Äôs the best thing in the world.‚Äù

If Rachel‚Äôs journey speaks to you, fostering might be the next chapter in your life too.

items.title: Meet Wayne Brown: North West Registered Manager
items.snippet: Strong and compassionate leadership, along with consistent and steady support, make this possible, and our Registered Managers play an important role in nurturing that support and maintaining the high standards we are known for. The post Meet Wayne Brown: North West Registered Manager appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
At Swiis Foster Care, our foster carers and the wider team work closely together to care for and improve the lives of children and young people in foster care. Strong and compassionate leadership, along with consistent and steady support, make this possible, and our Registered Managers play an important role in nurturing that support and maintaining the high standards we are known for.

Meet Wayne Brown, our Registered Manager in the North West. He is passionate about supporting foster carers and helping children and young people in care reach their full potential. He loves being part of a team that makes a meaningful difference in their lives every day.

Outside of work, Wayne stays busy by regularly going to the gym, alongside being into music, which is a big part of his life. He is a producer, keyboard player, vocalist, and bass player, and runs his own recording studio. Wayne created a nine-piece band called INNERGROOVE, who have recently released a new single on Spotify!

We spoke to Wayne about the role of Registered Manager, what made him choose fostering, what he loves about his role and his thoughts on what makes a truly great foster carer.

Can you tell us about your journey working within foster care? What experiences have shaped your path, and what motivates you to keep making a difference in this field?

‚ÄúGrowing up, my mum was a foster carer, so I spent my childhood in a home where looked-after children were very much part of the family. That experience inspired me to become a support worker, where I took children out, went to activities, and did focused work with them.

‚ÄúAt the age of 21, I became a foster carer myself alongside working as a support worker. I initially started as a respite carer for my mum before being approved as a full-time foster carer. I did this for three years before focusing more on the support worker role. I later became the regional support manager for the service, and was in this role for 5 years, but then decided I wanted to cast the net and learn more about the wider role, so I was sponsored to complete a social work degree.

‚ÄúFrom there, I progressed through roles including supervising social worker, team manager, and registered manager at another organisation with two Outstanding (in all areas) Ofsted inspections under my belt whilst working there. I eventually joined Swiis because I wanted to be part of an organisation where the focus is genuinely on children rather than recruitment or profit. Nearly a year in, I can honestly say that the values, ethics, and morals here are in the right place.‚Äù

In what ways have your childhood experiences in a fostering household, along with your own journey as a foster carer, shaped the way you support foster carers today?

‚ÄúGrowing up in a fostering household showed me the variety of children who can come into a home and the different behaviours they can present. It also taught me that what you read on paper is not always what happens in real life. Most of the children my mum looked after brought a sense of fun and energy, but naturally, some of the children presented challenges, which was understandable given their experiences. This insight, in addition to the training I attended, helped me understand the impact of trauma and how that can manifest in their behaviour.

‚ÄúI often think about new foster carers preparing for their first child coming to live with them. There is excitement, nerves, and lots of questions about what to buy or how to get ready. Things may not go exactly as planned, and that is okay.

‚ÄúFrom my own experience as a foster carer, I remember feeling excited about a new child coming to live with me and wanting everything to be perfect. When it didn‚Äôt go that way, it was initially deflating, but it taught me the importance of communication. Being kept informed and updated at every step would have made me feel calmer and more prepared.

‚ÄúThat lesson has stayed with me and shapes the way we work at Swiis. It is about keeping foster carers informed, letting them know if things change, and showing respect through open and honest communication.‚Äù

Your Role at Swiis Foster Care

Could you share a bit about your role ‚Äî what it involves and what a typical day tends to look like for you?

‚ÄúI am the Registered Manager here at Swiis North West, and I have been with the team just under a year. Since joining, there have been a lot of transitions, but together we have built a really strong hub with great energy across the team.

‚ÄúWe recently had an ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô result in our latest Ofsted inspection in November 2025, which is a true reflection of the team, our wonderful foster carers, and young people. The service was already outstanding when I joined, and since then, we have been able to build on that foundation and are now rated ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô in all areas.

‚ÄúDay to day, there are a lot of meetings that I take part in as part of my role. I meet regularly with the Stability and Support team, and I also have weekly catch-ups with the admin team to make sure everyone is on the same page and prepared for the week ahead.

‚ÄúDuring the panels, I sit in as the panel advisor, where my role is to provide guidance on Swiis policies and procedures and support the decision-making process.

‚ÄúAlongside all of this, I produce reports on the service we provide and highlight any issues that arise. That all happens before I even start working directly with the foster carers and the team. As part of my role, I am directly responsible to Ofsted. It is a very dynamic job, and no two days are the same.‚Äù

What do you enjoy most about working at Swiis?

‚ÄúThe people and the team! We have a really strong ethos here, and everyone looks out for each other, and there is a great energy across the whole team. The recent ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô report from Ofsted has really reinforced that. That honesty and willingness to learn is where our real strength lies.‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel it is rewarding sitting in foster carer reviews and panels, listening to the great work our foster carers do, attending activities and getting to know the young people. I try to be as directly involved as possible.‚Äù

How do you help your team bring the Swiis values to life in their day‚Äëto‚Äëday work?

‚ÄúIt is about keeping everyone aligned, energised, and engaged, and helping them buy into the vision of what we do, which is ultimately supporting foster carers so they can support children. I am really proud of the team we have. We have fantastic support workers, an amazing Education Advisor, brilliant deputy managers, administrators, and other team members who are centrally based, everyone works together as one.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a really rewarding environment to be part of, and I couldn‚Äôt be happier with the team we have built in the North West.‚Äù

During the North West‚Äôs recent Outstanding Ofsted inspection, you were praised for going above and beyond in building relationships with children, foster carers, and staff. Could you share some examples of how you did this and the difference you felt it made?

‚ÄúI think it’s all about building personal relationships, and if you are just sending emails or giving the occasional message, you are not really connecting with people. I make it a point to be in the room with them. I attend activities, support groups, and connect with foster carers and children whenever I can.

‚ÄúWhen I first joined, I met with all the North West foster carers, and now, with every new foster carer that joins, I go out with the supervising social worker to see them and to go through their carer agreement and get to know them personally. It is about putting a face to a name and making foster carers feel at ease. I want them to know that I am not just someone who turns up when there is a problem and that I am always at the end of the phone if they need support.

‚ÄúWith the team, we work very much as a collective rather than a hierarchy. If a social worker is busy, I will step in and support with visits or other tasks. I think leading by example is important. I would never ask anyone to do something that I would not be willing to do myself. Showing that mindset helps bring energy and motivation to the team and ultimately supports better outcomes for children and foster carers.‚Äù

In your view, what qualities make someone a great foster carer?

‚ÄúI think a great foster carer is someone who doesn‚Äôt take themselves too seriously and doesn‚Äôt take things personally, as children can sometimes say things that are not meant in the way they come across. Having a good sense of humour is really important, along with integrity, so if you say you are going to do something, you follow through. Being child-centred and a child-focused advocate, as well as flexible and creative, also plays a huge part in supporting children in the best possible way. In addition to the practical tasks (which are plenty!), keeping on top of training and recording completes the role in my view.‚Äù

Wayne‚Äôs reflections on fostering and supporting foster carers highlights our commitment to creating positive outcomes for children and young people in care.

By celebrating the teams and individuals who make Swiis exceptional, we aim to demonstrate our dedication to supporting foster carers and the children they care for every step of the way.

The post Meet Wayne Brown: North West Registered Manager appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.

items.title: Children‚Äôs Mental Health Week: This Is My Place
items.snippet: TACT are supporting Children's Mental Health Week by highlighting some tips on how to promote a sense of belonging. The post Children‚Äôs Mental Health Week: This Is My Place appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
Children‚Äôs Mental Health Week: This Is My Place

February 9th-15th 2026 sees the return of The Place to Be‚Äôs Children‚Äôs Mental Health Week. The theme for this year is This Is My Place with a focus on supporting the systems around children to help them feel they belong.

Promoting a sense of belonging

There have been a number of theories and models published over many years which explore the benefits of children feeling that they belong including Maslow‚Äôs Hierarchy of Needs (1957) and Belongingness Hypothesis (Baumeister & Leary 1995). It‚Äôs widely recognised across the health and social care professions that promoting a sense of belonging is not only required to help a child reach their full potential but is essential for a child‚Äôs overall emotional and physiological health. Research studies and findings demonstrate that when children feel connected, accepted, and valued within their family, school, and community – they are better able to form secure relationships, which supports healthy emotional development and positive self-esteem. A strong sense of belonging also reduces stress and anxiety, lowering cortisol levels and supporting healthy brain development, sleep, and immune functioning.

Creating environments where children and young people feel they truly belong can provide the foundation needed for both emotional stability and overall physiological wellbeing. Foster carers can play a crucial role in promoting and developing this sense of belonging by intentionally creating opportunities for connection, inclusion, and developing a shared identity. 

By engaging in simple, regular activities, such as those detailed below, they can help make a child feel valued and a ‚Äòpart of the family‚Äô. Taking time to learn about the child‚Äôs background, culture, and interests, and weaving these into daily life, can also help them feel respected and understood.

Below are some suggestions for different activities which are designed to promote feelings of belonging.

Create a welcoming environment

  • Create a cosy, comfortable and inviting family space for spending downtime together.
  • Allow children to decorate and personalise their own spaces. Get involved in doing this and you can even extend by doing craft activities first such as creating mood or vision boards to capture and share ideas.
  • Allow children to incorporate and share their own personal touches or personality across the house, not just in their bedrooms.
  • Display artwork, medals, trophies, certificates for everyone to see and celebrate.

Introduce daily routines and/or rituals

  • Do a daily check in where each person shares the best part of their day, the worst and something funny or random.
  • Have set mealtimes where everyone eats together. Use this time to share stories, talk about your day and unplug from technology.
  • Have consistent and established routines for the beginning and end of the day which focus on positive interactions.
  • Read a book together – it could be a bedtime story, helping with reading or share a book with an older child/teen.
  • Introduce ‚Äòswitch off time‚Äô by encouraging children to unplug from their electronic devices and engage in a different activity or interest. Share this time with them if possible.
  • Embrace technology – have a family group chat which is used to promote bonding but be mindful if setting boundaries!

Do an activity together, as a family

  • Get crafty and creative! Draw pictures, create treasure boxes, build Lego, make monster pompoms, paint rocks and hide them outdoors for people to find, do an ‚Äòall about me‚Äô portrait, create cards to send to others.
  • Create a wish tree – decorate a small tree or branch with tags or baubles with hopes, wishes or positive messages for one another.
  • Cook a meal together which explores different cultures and traditions.
  • Get outdoors ‚Äì go for a walk, do some work in the garden, play at the park (grownups can still fit on swings too!).
  • Have a family game night playing board games or card games.
  • Pick a TV series and watch together without the interruption of other devices or interests.
  • Print pictures and display them! They could be put in frames or added to scrapbooks or displays/pinboards.
  • Enjoy a day out ‚Äì don‚Äôt use this as a reward, just for connection and having fun.

Build emotional connections and affirmations

  • Encourage small and regular Random Acts of Kindness, recognise and praise these.
  • Create an ‚Äòall about me‚Äô box for storing or sharing important items that represent everyone‚Äôs unique identities.
  • Share interests and get involved ‚Äì yes, standing pitch side is cold in the winter but being there builds connections and feelings of belonging.
  • Celebrate achievements and share these with others in the household.
  • Encourage and model sharing and reflecting on emotions safely.
  • Take time to play and have fun!
  • For children who are unable to articulate their feelings, find ways for them to share through non-verbal means.

Mechelle Holley – TACT Health Commissioning & Performance Manager

The post Children‚Äôs Mental Health Week: This Is My Place appeared first on TACT.

items.title: Why We Need More Young Foster Parents
items.snippet: In your 20s or 30s and want to make a difference? Fostering could be the perfect path. In this blog, we explore why more young foster carers are needed, how you can meet the requirements, and why your energy, empathy, and fresh perspective could change a child‚Äôs life for the better. The post Why We Need More Young Foster Parents appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
Are you in your 20s or 30s, reflecting on how you could make a real difference in the world? Then, fostering children is a brilliant way to do just that.

Every year, 36,000 children move into care, but the number of foster families available to care for them is decreasing. These children have often experienced the unimaginable and need the stability of a loving home and family to care for them.

From the initial requirements to foster and why you could be the ideal foster parent, to frequently asked questions about fostering when you’re a bit younger, join us as we explore fostering in your 20s and 30s.

Can you foster children in your 20s and 30s?

Yes, if you have the passion for helping the most vulnerable children and young people in the UK, you can foster in your 20s and 30s. There are just a few initial requirements:

  • You must be 21 or over.
  • You must have a spare bedroom
  • You must be legally able to work in the UK.

You don‚Äôt need to have raised or be raising your own family, nor do you need any specific experience, because when you foster with FCA, you‚Äôll receive extensive training, a generous foster carer allowance, and support throughout your fostering journey.

Read on to discover why, as a younger person, you could be the ideal foster parent.

Why younger people make great foster parents

Becoming a foster parent when you‚Äôre younger has lots of benefits for both you and the children you foster. Here are our top five.

No preconceived parenting ideas

Although fostering and parenting are similar in lots of ways, they are also quite different in others.

Many children and young people in care have had difficult pasts, which means they are often living with trauma. This impacts their entire well-being, from their ability to regulate and communicate their emotions to the way they behave and build connections with others.

These children need trauma-informed care to help them recover from their experiences and begin building a brighter future.

When foster parents have had children of their own who have grown up and fled the nest, it can be more challenging for them to relearn trauma-informed methods because they’ve become so used to applying more traditional parenting approaches.

However, if you haven’t had children of your own yet, or they are still fairly young, it’s unlikely that you’ll have any preconceived parenting ideas, making it easier to adapt to the needs of children and young people in your care.

Less of a generational gap

When you foster in your 20s and 30s, the age difference between you and the children you foster is less significant than the average age of a foster parent, which is 54.

You’ll likely be more familiar with technology, current slang, mental health issues, and other challenges children and young people face today. This can make it easier for young people in your care to relate to you about the problems they might be facing during their teenage years.

As a result, this could help you build a strong bond with the children you foster, as you’ll be more prepared to support them in navigating the ups and downs of life.

More energy to fulfil your role

The roles and responsibilities of foster carers mean you need lots of energy, an eagerness to learn, and a willingness to adapt to the changing needs of children in your care.

From school drop-offs, meetings, and appointments to family time arrangements, days out, and more, foster parent life, although rewarding, can also be demanding.

Being a young foster parent often means you’ll have more energy and patience to manage your ever-changing schedule without burning out, making your home more stable for children and young people.

Breaking down stereotypes and role modelling

Many people believe that you need to have years of life experience to be a good foster parent. Although it can be helpful if you’ve raised your own children or worked in a similar profession, it‚Äôs not necessary, and these misconceptions can prevent younger people from even considering fostering as an option.

But if you decide to take this step and open your home to the children and young people who need it most, you‚Äôll break down stereotypes and encourage others to do the same.

You‚Äôll also show your foster children how to manage young adulthood, inspiring them to follow their dreams and build healthy futures.

You can change more lives

Although there is no foster care age limit, if you begin your fostering journey later in life, there is a possibility it could be cut short by health concerns, as they are more likely to occur as you get older.

But when you begin your fostering journey in your 20s or 30s, you have more time to make a difference.

Whether you foster a child long-term, seeing them through to adulthood and beyond, or provide emergency fostering or respite care and welcome multiple children into your home, you‚Äôll have years in front of you to transform young lives.

FAQs about fostering in your 20s and 30s

We recognise that becoming a foster parent is a life-changing decision, so we‚Äôve selected the most common questions we‚Äôre asked here at FCA about fostering from younger people to help you make an informed decision.

Can you earn a living as a foster carer?

One of the most pressing questions we‚Äôre asked by those considering fostering in their 20s and 30s is, How much do you get paid to foster?

Although we know money isn‚Äôt the primary motivation to become a foster parent, it’s understandable that you’d want to make sure that you’ll feel financially secure on your fostering journey.

The good news is that when you foster with FCA, you’ll receive a generous fostering allowance per child, per year, which is typically tax-free. You’ll also benefit from additional perks, such as bonus payments, length-of-service rewards, and discounts on our foster parent rewards platform.

Can you foster as a single person?

Absolutely, many of our foster parents choose to foster as a single person. However, during the application process, we‚Äôll need to make sure that you have support from friends and family to make your journey more manageable.

You‚Äôll also receive support from our incredible community, including social workers, education co-ordinators, therapists, experienced foster parents and more, so you‚Äôll never feel like you‚Äôre doing it alone.

From support groups and meet-ups to events like the Big Sing Off, you’ll feel welcomed and ready to see where your journey takes you.

Can you foster if you rent your home?

Yes, you don‚Äôt need to own your own home to foster. However, you will need permission from your landlord, and you must have a spare bedroom for a child to make their own.

You can also move house while fostering, but if you plan to do so within a few months of approval, we will ask you to apply to foster once you’ve settled in.

Is there room for progression?

At FCA, we‚Äôre committed to your personal and professional development. That‚Äôs why when you foster with us, you‚Äôll receive ongoing training that will not only prepare you for each stage of your fostering journey, but also broaden your knowledge and skills so you can provide more specialist foster care, such as disability fostering.

Can you work while fostering?

Yes, you can work alongside fostering; however, it depends on the hours you work, the flexibility of your employer, the age of the children you foster, and whether you foster as a couple or on your own.

Our priority is the well-being of children in your care, and you’ll need to be available for school drop-offs and holidays, meetings, appointments, training, and all other responsibilities that come with fostering a child.

Ready to start a meaningful career?

If you‚Äôre ready to start a meaningful career in fostering and would like to learn more, get in touch today.

Call us on 0800 023 4561 or submit an enquiry form. Our friendly team are ready to answer your questions and help you get started on your fostering journey.

items.title: Celebrating a full house of Ofsted ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô Reports
items.snippet: Following Ofsted inspections across the Midlands and South, North East and North West and with Yorkshire already holding an ‚ÄòOfsted Outstanding‚Äô accreditation, every one of our offices have once again been awarded the highest possible rating of ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô across all areas of our service. The post Celebrating a full house of Ofsted ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô Reports appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
2025 has been a truly exceptional year for Swiis Foster Care. Following Ofsted inspections across the Midlands and South, North East and North West and with Yorkshire already holding an ‚ÄòOfsted Outstanding‚Äô accreditation, every one of our offices have once again been awarded the highest possible rating of ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô across all areas of our service.

Consistently achieving Ofsted‚Äôs highest rating is an exceptional accomplishment within the fostering sector, attained by only a small number of agencies nationwide. Through sustained excellence and unwavering commitment to children and young people, Swiis stands among a select and respected small group of UK fostering providers currently holding multiple ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô ratings simultaneously.

Ofsted‚Äôs inspection report celebrates not only the quality of provision but the life-changing impact of Swiis‚Äôs work, noting:

‚Äú(Swiis), the independent fostering agency provides highly effective services that consistently exceed the standards of good. The actions of the independent fostering agency contribute to significantly improved outcomes and positive experiences for children and young people.‚Äù

What Does Being an Ofsted ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô Fostering Agency Mean?

Being rated ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô by Ofsted is more than an impressive achievement. It is a clear indication that children and young people experience the highest quality care and support possible, enabling them to achieve their goals and ambitions that they may not have been able to. It reflects consistently excellent practice, robust safeguarding, and exceptional leadership across every part of our agency.

For the Children and Young People in Our Care

For children, this means they feel safe, valued, and genuinely heard by our foster carers and staff. They are supported to grow in confidence, achieve their goals, and experience the stability and encouragement they need to thrive. It shows that their voices matter and that their wellbeing is at the heart of everything we do.

For Our Foster Carers

For foster carers, this recognition reflects the high-quality training, guidance and round-the-clock support they receive, as well as the positive, lasting difference they make to the lives of the children in their care. Swiis foster carers are among the best in the sector, consistently providing nurturing, stable homes where children and young people feel safe, valued and able to thrive.

Swiis foster carers know they are never alone. They are part of a supportive community, backed by a dedicated team who are always there, listening, guiding and standing alongside them, fully committed to their success and to the wellbeing and future of every child and young person in their care.

As a Fostering Agency

Ofsted only awards ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô when a fostering agency consistently goes above and beyond for their foster carers and the children within their care. Having consistently ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô ratings in all areas across our Midlands and South, North East, Yorkshire and North West offices is an exceptionally proud achievement for all Swiis staff.

This accomplishment reflects the dedication, compassion and professionalism of every member of the Swiis team. It is a testament to the hard work our staff put in every day and to our unwavering commitment to achieving the best possible outcomes for children and young people.

Highlights From Our Ofsted Reports

Across the Midlands and South, North East, Yorkshire and North West, children receive nurturing, individualised care that helps them make exceptional progress. Many enjoy long-term, stable home arrangements, building trusting and meaningful relationships with their foster carers.

Below, we have shared just a small selection of the wonderful feedback highlighted by Ofsted. If you would like to explore our reports in full, you can find them on the Government website here:

North East Ofsted Report North West Ofsted Report Midlands & South Ofsted Report Yorkshire Ofsted Report

Support for Children and Young People‚Äôs Educational Needs

Education is a key strength, with children attending school regularly, consistently achieving above expectations, and benefiting from specialist support tailored to their individual learning needs. Swiis places strong emphasis on children‚Äôs engagement with education, ensuring their commitment and participation are actively supported. Every achievement, big or small, is recognised and celebrated by our teams, helping children build confidence and feel empowered to aspire to and reach their goals.

‚ÄúSpecialist and bespoke support is provided by a dedicated team that works alongside children to break down any barriers to their learning.‚Äù – Midlands and South Ofsted Report

‚ÄúChildren‚Äôs education and learning progress are at the forefront of the agency‚Äôs practice.‚Äù – North East Ofsted Report

Swiis Education Advisors work closely with children and foster carers to understand each child‚Äôs unique learning needs and provide tailored guidance to overcome challenges. By prioritising education, Swiis ensures that every child and young person has the best possible opportunity to succeed, develop confidence, and achieve their full potential, while foster carers feel fully supported in helping children reach their goals.

Our Dedicated Stability and Support Team

Swiis‚Äôs Stability & Support Team provides foster carers with an additional layer of personalised guidance and one-to-one support, helping them respond confidently to any concerns or behaviours a child or young person may present. From the very beginning of their fostering journey, carers can access practical advice and proven strategies to support them through any challenging moments.  The Stability and Support Team can be accessed directly by the foster carer if preferred and is in addition to the exceptional daily support of the social work teams.  This wrap around support ensures foster carers are well equipped to create safe, nurturing environments where children can thrive, grow and overcome barriers they may face.

‚ÄúFoster carers feel exceptionally well supported and valued by agency staff, which impacts positively on the outcomes of children who are thriving in their foster families.‚Äù – North West Ofsted Report

Exceptional Safeguarding

Safeguarding is at the heart of everything we do at Swiis. Children and young people feel safe, supported and valued in our foster homes, cared for by experienced foster carers and supported by highly skilled and committed social work teams. We operate robust and comprehensive safeguarding processes to ensure the highest standards of safety and wellbeing for every child in our care.

Safeguarding is also central to our recruitment, assessment and approval processes. All foster carers and Swiis staff go through rigorous checks and preparation, ensuring they are well trained, confident and fully supported in their role. This strong safeguarding framework promotes stability and enables foster carers to provide safe, nurturing homes where children can thrive.

‚ÄúSafeguarding children is at the centre of the agency.‚Äù – Midlands and South Ofsted Report

At Swiis, every decision and action prioritises the safety and well-being of children. This gives foster carers confidence that they are fully supported when protecting children, knowing they are not alone in ensuring the highest standards of care. Children, in turn, feel secure, protected, and able to build trust with the foster carers caring for them.

Comprehensive and Relevant Training

Swiis provides foster carers with comprehensive and practical training, giving them the knowledge and confidence they need to meet children‚Äôs diverse needs. Well-trained foster carers can respond effectively to both every day and complex situations, helping children feel secure, supported, and understood at all times.

‚ÄúHighly effective post-approval training ensures that foster carers have the relevant skills and knowledge to undertake the fostering role.‚Äù – North West Ofsted Report

Child-Focused Leadership and Staff

Swiis is led by experienced leaders who provide strong oversight and inspire continuous improvement. Staff morale is high, workloads are manageable, and teams work closely together to deliver consistent, high-quality care. All regions have strong partnerships with other professionals to ensure children remain at the centre of all practice.

‚ÄúFoster carers have provided overwhelmingly positive feedback about the support they receive from the agency.‚Äù – Midlands and South Ofsted Report

Foster carers consistently report feeling valued, supported, and heard. This strengthens fostering home-finding arrangements, enabling children to thrive in stable, nurturing homes where their emotional and developmental needs are met.

‚ÄúStaff morale is high, and staff say that they love their job.‚Äù – North East Ofsted Report

Motivated and passionate staff ensure children receive consistent, high-quality care. When staff feel proud and inspired by their work, it directly benefits foster carers and children, creating a supportive environment where everyone can flourish.

‚ÄúSocial workers have manageable caseloads and are in weekly contact with their foster carers.‚Äù – North West Ofsted Report

Regular, meaningful contact allows social workers to provide timely guidance, reassurance, and practical support. This ensures foster carers are equipped to meet children‚Äôs needs effectively, helping children feel safe, cared for, and supported at every stage of their fostering journey.

A Huge Thank You!

We would like to extend our heartfelt thanks to our foster carers, the children, and young people in our care, and every member of the Swiis team. Your dedication, commitment, and collaboration are at the heart of these ‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô achievements. These Ofsted results celebrate the care, passion, and teamwork that make Swiis a truly exceptional fostering service.

The post Celebrating a full house of Ofsted ¬†‚ÄòOutstanding‚Äô Reports appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.

items.title: Swiis Foster Care: Highlights of an Extraordinary 2025
items.snippet: 2025 has been a year where children have thrived, foster carers have felt truly supported, and our teams have gone above and beyond to deliver life-changing care. The post Swiis Foster Care: Highlights of an Extraordinary 2025 appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
2025 has been a truly remarkable year for Swiis Foster Care, a year defined by commitment, compassion, and collective excellence. Above all else, it has been a year where children have thrived, foster carers have felt truly supported, and our teams have gone above and beyond to deliver life-changing care.

A Landmark Year: Ofsted Outstanding ‚Äì Three Times Over

The pinnacle of 2025 came in the latter part of the year, when Swiis Foster Care achieved an exceptional milestone: three Ofsted inspections, each awarded Outstanding across all areas. This achievement means that all Swiis regions, including Yorkshire, the North East, the North West, the Midlands and South, are officially rated Outstanding, the highest possible recognition across all areas of our service.

These inspections were embraced by every team member as an opportunity to showcase the exceptional work we do together. An Ofsted Outstanding rating is more than an accolade, it is recognition that children are not only safe but flourishing, supported by stable arrangements, highly skilled foster carers, and leadership that is relentless in its pursuit of excellence.

An outstanding award also reflects the fact that our foster carers are exceptionally well trained and supported, with robust safeguarding, strong professional relationships, and a culture of continuous improvement that truly puts children first.

“The independent fostering agency provides highly effective services that consistently exceed the standards of good. The actions of the independent fostering agency contribute to significantly improved outcomes and positive experiences for children and young people.” – Ofsted, 2025

North East Ofsted Report North West Ofsted Report Midlands & South Ofsted Report Yorkshire Ofsted Report

Children Thriving Through Stability and Belonging

At the heart of everything we do are our children, and this year, their achievements have been nothing short of inspiring. Across Swiis Foster Care, children have experienced increased stability, improved emotional well-being, and the confidence that comes from feeling safe, valued, and listened to.

Many of our children have made significant personal progress, overcoming early trauma with the help of consistent, nurturing foster arrangements. These achievements, whether it‚Äôs improved school attendance, renewed self-belief, learning new skills or simply learning to trust again, are powerful reminders of the impact that exceptional foster care can have on a child‚Äôs life.

Foster Carers: The Beating Heart of Swiis Foster Care

In 2025, Swiis Foster Care truly demonstrated that we are the agency of choice. We recruited the highest number of foster carers in our history, far exceeding the average for fostering agencies nationally. This extraordinary achievement reflects the trust carers place in Swiis and the reputation we have built for outstanding support, training, and care.

Our foster carers continue to show unwavering dedication, opening their hearts and homes to children who need them most. Their resilience, compassion, and commitment underpin every success we celebrate.

Support That Never Sleeps: 24/7, Every Day

At Swiis Foster Care, support doesn‚Äôt stop at office hours. Our foster carers have access to guidance and reassurance 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, ensuring that no concern, challenge, or unexpected situation is faced alone. This constant availability provides confidence, reassurance, and peace of mind, a cornerstone of our outstanding practice.

Rachel’s Fostering Story

‚ÄúFrom the very beginning, Swiis has been an incredible support system. They have listened to me when discussing my choices and have always supported my decisions. I truly believe we work as a team, and I always feel listened to, and I plan to continue fostering with Swiis until I retire.‚Äù

Read Rachel’s Fostering Story

Bianca’s Fostering Story

‚ÄúSwiis Foster Care have supported us every step of the way. The assessment process and initial training were both realistic and supportive, and we have made positive relationships with all the Swiis staff. What makes Swiis different is that the teams are genuinely interested in carers and the children, and that makes a big difference.‚Äù

Read Bianca’s Fostering Story

Going Beyond: The Stability and Support Team

A few years ago, Swiis Foster Care took an innovative step to further enhance support by developing a specialist Stability and Support Team. Their role is to work directly with foster carers, offering tailored advice, practical strategies, and specialist guidance around behaviours and complex needs.

In 2025, this team had its busiest year yet. Demand grew as carers increasingly accessed this invaluable support, a clear testament to how impactful and trusted the service has become. In response, we expanded the team to ensure every foster carer receives timely, expert help when they need it most.

The team also introduced specialist forum groups and topical webinar training, with subjects chosen by our foster carers themselves. This collaborative approach has empowered carers, strengthened peer connections, and further enhanced the quality of care provided to children.

View The Stability & Support Team

Looking Ahead to 2026

As we reflect on 2025, we do so with immense pride. This was a year of outstanding achievement, heartfelt dedication, and genuine transformation for children, foster carers, and staff alike.

Together, we have shown what is possible when care, expertise, and passion come together. And as we look to the future, one thing remains certain: Swiis Foster Care will continue to go above and beyond, because every child deserves nothing less.

As we move into 2026, our commitment remains unwavering. At Swiis Foster Care, we will continue to evolve and strengthen the support we provide to both our foster carers and the children and young people in their care. Everything we do is guided by one clear purpose: ensuring that every child can feel safe, nurtured, and supported to achieve their full potential.

For those choosing to begin their fostering journey with Swiis, we are committed to making that experience as supportive, flexible, and stress-free as possible. From the very first conversation, through assessment, approval, and beyond, our focus is on supporting our carers every step of the way.

During the next few months, we will be sharing more about the wonderful achievements of our children, celebrating their progress, resilience, and successes. We will also be highlighting the vital role of our social work teams and our foster carers, alongside the specialist provision offered by our Stability and Support Team, giving greater insight into how this enhanced support continues to make a meaningful difference for carers and children alike.

In addition, we will be sharing more details about the feedback from our Ofsted Outstanding inspection outcomes, helping to demonstrate what outstanding practice looks like and how it directly benefits the children we support.

items.title: Debbie‚Äôs 15 Years of Fostering
items.snippet: Debbie has been fostering with FCA North West for 15 years. Over that time, she‚Äôs cared for many different children - from young babies and parent and child placements right through to older teenagers. The post Debbie‚Äôs 15 Years of Fostering appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
How it all began

Fostering had always been at the back of Debbie‚Äôs mind. She liked the idea of helping children who needed a safe, stable home but she just wasn‚Äôt sure when the right moment would be.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd always thought about fostering and thought it would be a nice thing to do,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúA friend of mine started fostering and said, ‚ÄòWould you like me to give you my social worker‚Äôs number?‚Äô And it all started from there.‚Äù

Moments that make it all worthwhile

Over the years, Debbie has welcomed many children with different backgrounds and needs. One young person stands out.

‚ÄúWe had a child come to live with us who was quite challenging at the time,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúHe was from another country, and his culture was very different to ours. It was challenging for him and for us.‚Äù

Debbie never expected him to stay in touch ‚Äî but he did.

‚ÄúWhen he left, I didn‚Äôt think he would keep in touch, but he did and he still does to this day. Any problems he has, or difficulties, or even achievements, he‚Äôll always come back and tell us, which is lovely.‚Äù

Another moment that means a lot to Debbie involves a young person she cares for now.

‚ÄúWhen she came to live with us, she found it quite difficult ‚Äî especially around men, including my husband,‚Äù Debbie says. ‚ÄúAs time went on, she got more relaxed. The moment she just went up and gave him a hug‚Ä¶ that was really, really nice. That was one of my favourite moments.‚Äù

The qualities that matter

Debbie believes empathy is the most important part of fostering.

‚ÄúYou need to have that empathy for children because they come from all different backgrounds,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúFor somebody to just turn up at your home and have to live with another family – it‚Äôs really, really hard. I‚Äôd find it difficult, let alone a little child.‚Äù

Support that‚Äôs always there

For Debbie, FCA‚Äôs support has made a big difference to her fostering journey.

‚ÄúWe receive lots of support from FCA, and it can be in different ways,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs something we‚Äôre finding difficult or challenging, we can always go and ask. If there‚Äôs something we‚Äôre not sure of, there’s always somebody on the end of the phone. Even if our social worker‚Äôs off, there‚Äôs always someone we can contact.‚Äù

Her advice?

After 15 years, Debbie still loves fostering – and she encourages others to explore it too.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre thinking about fostering, it‚Äôs worth finding out more. You don‚Äôt have to know everything, you just need to care. The rest comes with support.‚Äù

items.title: The New Year‚Äôs Resolution That Will Change a Child‚Äôs Life
items.snippet: Before you choose a New Year's Resolution like finding a new hobby or improving your health, why not consider making a New Year‚Äôs Resolution that will help others and change lives? The post The New Year‚Äôs Resolution That Will Change a Child‚Äôs Life appeared first on Orange Grove Foster Care.
items.content:
The start of a new year is the perfect time to try something new. Whether that‚Äôs finding a new hobby, starting a new job, or committing to new habits that will improve your health and wellbeing. But have you ever considered making a New Year‚Äôs Resolution that will help others?

Some of the best resolutions are those that have a profound impact on the lives of others. This could be things like volunteering at your local homeless shelter, raising money for a cause close to your heart, or perhaps even deciding to become a foster parent.

Resolutions that are centred around helping others are often the ones that we‚Äôre most motivated to succeed in. They also happen to be the ones that bring us the most joy, purpose and fulfilment.

As a fostering agency, we see firsthand the extraordinary difference foster parents can make to the lives of vulnerable children. It can also be such a rewarding experience for foster families and their children too. So, if you‚Äôve been thinking about fostering for some time, then why not make 2026 the year you‚ÄØapply to become a foster parent? You might just change a child‚Äôs life.

4 reasons to make fostering your New Year‚Äôs resolution

If you‚Äôre still unsure whether to take your first step towards looking after children, then here are 4 more reasons why deciding to start your fostering journey might just be the best New Year‚Äôs Resolution you‚Äôll ever make‚Ä¶

1. Change a Child‚Äôs World

There are over 80,000 children in care in England. Many of these children will have been through things that no child should ever have to experience. Whether that‚Äôs physical abuse, being left to fend for themselves, or losing a parent. Becoming a foster parent and giving a child in care all the love, nurture and support they need will help make an extraordinary difference to their future.

Plus, there are so many different ways that you can help look after children. You may wish to start by offering short-term foster care to children, which means you will be in a child‚Äôs life for up to two years. This is often while they‚Äôre going through court proceedings, which can be an incredibly turbulent and distressing time.

Or you may want to be a‚ÄØlong-term foster parent, where you welcome a child into your home for many years until they turn 18. This is a completely different experience of fostering, where a child can truly become part of your family. Often, the bonds developed over these years continue into adulthood too.

All types of fostering can be incredibly rewarding, and whichever path you choose, you really can change a child‚Äôs world.

2. Fostering Can Be Great Fun

While there will be challenging days when you foster ‚Äì like raising any child ‚Äì there will also be so many great times that you‚Äôll share together.

As a foster parent, you‚Äôll help children in your care experience the childhood they deserve ‚Äì and this can be a lot of fun. Whether it‚Äôs taking them on their first holiday, watching them take to the stage at the school panto, or singing and dancing to their favourite songs in the kitchen while you‚Äôre preparing dinner. Children bring so much joy and laughter to our lives, and you can do the same for them.

3. Provide Stability When They Need It the Most

If you stop to think about it, children in foster care are there with you because they can‚Äôt be with their parents right now ‚Äì perhaps ever. They‚Äôve already seen some of the worst that life has to throw at them and often feel all alone in a world that is crumbling down around them.

You can help them to feel less isolated as they navigate the world around them, and it may not be as difficult as you think. Sometimes all it takes is just being there, just showing them that you are not going anywhere. That sense of stability is what they need most and can really make a difference to children in foster care.

4. The Application Process is a Journey, Not a Commitment

Remember, just by taking that first step to learn more about fostering doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre committed. The‚ÄØfostering application process‚ÄØis a journey that will help you discover whether fostering is right for you and, if you‚Äôre right for fostering.

Plus, at Orange Grove, we will always move at a pace that‚Äôs right for you. You will never feel pressured to move to the next stage if you don‚Äôt feel ready.

We are committed to providing the training and support that you need throughout the entire fostering process, from in person training to e-learning. You will also have an experienced team around you to give you and your family all the support that you need at each step of your journey.

Start your fostering journey here

Download our brochure and discover everything you need to know about fostering with Orange Grove.

DOWNLOAD GUIDE

Are You Ready to Take Your First Step in 2026?

‚ÄúWe wish we started fostering sooner,‚Äù is something we hear our foster parents say all the time. Our message to anyone considering fostering would be not to wait for the ‚Äòperfect time‚Äô to start. If you adore children and have the time, space and energy to commit to making a difference, then make 2026 the year you start your fostering journey.

And in case you hadn‚Äôt thought of it,‚ÄØbecoming a foster parent‚ÄØwill change your life as well as the children in your care. Once you welcome a child into your home, you almost always gain a better appreciation for all the things you do have and are able to do.

Maybe this year we can resolve to be there for a child. After all, it only takes one child at a time to make a real difference, and that‚Äôs a resolution worth keeping.

items.title: From Empty Nest to a Full Home ‚Äì Tracy‚Äôs Fostering Story
items.snippet: Tracy shares how fostering with FCA helped her turn an empty nest into a loving home, keeping siblings together and helping children thrive. The post From Empty Nest to a Full Home ‚Äì Tracy‚Äôs Fostering Story appeared first on Foster Care Associates.
items.content:
Tracy, from Southport in Merseyside, started fostering with her husband in 2022

When her birth children grew older and became more independent, she felt a shift at home, that familiar ‚Äúempty nest‚Äù feeling and knew she was ready for a new challenge.

‚ÄúWhen my birth children left home, it was like a bit of an empty nest,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThey went to high school, became more independent, and I wanted a new career in childcare. So, I looked into fostering, got some information, found out about it‚Ä¶ had lots of appointments, found out loads of details, and then decided to give it a go.‚Äù

Tracy‚Äôs introduction to fostering

Tracy‚Äôs first three years as a foster parent were with her local authority in Shropshire. But after relocating to the North West, she felt ready for a fresh start.

‚ÄúOn our relocation, I got in touch with a foster carer who recommended FCA,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúSo I got in touch with the agency. Somebody came round, we had a chat, and we went through the process again and joined FCA North West.‚Äù

Keeping siblings together

Their first foster child was part of a sibling group, but only one child could be placed with them at the time. It made a lasting impact.

‚ÄúWe saw the grief of a child who‚Äôd been separated from her siblings,‚Äù Tracy says. ‚ÄúSo when she left our care, we decided we wanted a bigger family home so we could foster sibling groups. We wanted to keep them together.‚Äù

That decision shaped everything that came next. Now Tracy and her husband care for three sisters, aged seven, eight and nine. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had them for the last three years,‚Äù she says proudly. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre long-term matched with me.‚Äù

Watching children thrive

For Tracy, the real highlights of fostering are the moments of growth.

‚ÄúThe highlights of fostering, I‚Äôd say, are seeing the child thrive, grow and smile in your care,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúTo know that they can be happy and get on with their lives and still have contact with their birth family.‚Äù

One teenager stands out in her mind.

‚ÄúShe came into care having lots of difficulties at school. Through care, nurture and help, we got her back into a mainstream school. We got her the help she needed ‚Äî the diagnoses she needed. She was actually dyslexic, but she‚Äôd been classed as a naughty child, a distracted child. With support, she sat her exams. That was a massive change.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe support with FCA is absolutely amazing.‚Äù

When Tracy talks about FCA, she doesn‚Äôt hesitate. ‚ÄúThe support with FCA is absolutely amazing ‚Äî one of the main reasons we made the decision to go with this agency,‚Äù she says.

And the support comes in all shapes and sizes.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs foster carer get-togethers, activities they put on for the children ‚Äî including birth families. We have monthly support groups in the North West. We meet at the Chorley office. There‚Äôs always something going on.‚Äù

Her advice to others?

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre thinking about fostering, I‚Äôd say give FCA a call. They‚Äôll answer any questions you have on the phone. You can find out so much from them that you‚Äôll want to have a go.

‚ÄúJust give it a try. Just give it a try.‚Äù

items.title: Carl and Jackie‚Äôs Story: Keeping siblings together and building lasting bonds
items.snippet: Carl and Jackie began fostering with Fosterplus after their own children had grown up and left home, opening their door and hearts to children who needed a stable, loving family. The post Carl and Jackie‚Äôs Story: Keeping siblings together and building lasting bonds appeared first on Fosterplus.
items.content:
Carl and Jackie began fostering with Fosterplus after their own children had grown up and left home.

Over seven years, they‚Äôve cared for long-term placements and sibling groups, offered short breaks to other foster families, and experienced first-hand how important it is to keep brothers and sisters together and build strong, lasting bonds with the children in their care. Their story shows how life experience, patience and a supportive fostering team can help children feel they truly belong.

Carl and Jackie had raised their own children, watched them grow up and leave home, and suddenly found themselves with a quiet house and a spare bedroom in Doncaster. They weren‚Äôt ready to slow down ‚Äì and they both felt they still had more to give.

‚ÄúWe decided to foster because we wanted to give something back and help somebody out,‚Äù Carl explains. With their children grown and grandchildren regularly visiting, they knew they had time, space and patience to offer ‚Äì they just needed to take the first step.

After researching agencies, they chose Fosterplus and started the journey of becoming a foster parent. The assessment, training and panel felt intense at times, but for Carl and Jackie it was all about making sure fostering would work not only for them, but for the children coming into their family and for their grandchildren too.

Fostering later in life ‚Äì and using every bit of experience

Carl and Jackie began fostering in their later years, but see that as a strength rather than a barrier. They‚Äôve raised children, welcomed grandchildren and weathered family ups and downs. That experience gives them perspective when things feel tough.¬†With teenagers in particular, Carl finds that shared understanding helps him stay calm and connect.

They chose to foster children aged 4‚Äì18 so they could match their energy and lifestyle to the needs of the children. For anyone wondering if they‚Äôre ‚Äútoo old‚Äù to foster, Carl and Jackie are very clear: if you can offer love, time and stability, age shouldn‚Äôt stop you.

Curious about fostering later in life

Discover everything you need to know from our ‘who can foster’ page.

Who Can Foster

Choosing to keep siblings together

After their first long-term placement with an 11-year-old boy, Carl and Jackie were asked to consider something new: fostering a brother and sister who had previously lived with another foster family.

Initially, there were questions about whether the siblings should stay together. Carl‚Äôs instinct was immediate and firm ‚Äì if they were going to foster, they wanted both children.

He knew that for many children in care, their brothers or sisters are the one constant link to their past, their family and their identity. Research shows that placing siblings together can lead to more stable, positive outcomes, wherever it‚Äôs safe and appropriate to do so.

So Carl and Jackie said yes ‚Äì on the condition that the siblings stayed together.

The early days were loud, emotional and full of adjustment. There were slammed doors, stomping up the stairs and plenty of bickering. But as Carl and Jackie got to know each child as an individual, they also began to see how much the two meant to each other.

Their home became a place where sibling relationships were protected and understood, even on the difficult days, showing just how important fostering siblings can be in helping children maintain their identity, connection and sense of belonging.

Belonging, identity and bonds that go both ways

For Carl and Jackie, fostering is as much about belonging as it is about everyday routines.

Over time, they noticed subtle changes. A child who once ran upstairs and slammed doors began staying to talk things through. Another, who first wanted to be introduced as a ‚Äúfoster child‚Äù, later chose to simply be seen as one of the grandchildren on a family holiday.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs about belonging,‚Äù Jackie reflects. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre starting to understand who they are, and where they fit ‚Äì and we‚Äôre part of that picture now.‚Äù

Their bond with the children has been tested and strengthened through some deeply personal moments too. When Carl and Jackie lost their adult son, they offered their foster son the chance to go into respite, knowing their home would be a sad and unsettled place for a while.

Instead, he chose to stay. He told them he was part of the family ‚Äì that he‚Äôd been there for the laughs, so he wanted to be there for the tears as well. For Carl and Jackie, that simple decision said everything about the two-way bond they had built.

Small steps that change a child‚Äôs world

Some of Carl and Jackie‚Äôs favourite memories are simple, ordinary moments that reveal how far a child has come.¬†Their foster daughter is naturally anxious and easily startled by loud noises. On a holiday in France, she initially refused to go into a freshwater lake, choosing instead to ‚Äúguard the bikes‚Äù on the shore. Carl and Jackie didn‚Äôt push ‚Äì they let her set the pace.

Slowly, she edged closer to the water. First paddling at the shoreline, then splashing in the shallows, and finally swimming in the lake, laughing with them as if she‚Äôd been doing it all her life.¬†For Jackie, watching that transformation from fear to joy in her own time, was one of their proudest fostering moments.

Another young person, who stayed for just three days, sent a message on her 18th birthday to thank them for their kindness and ask to stay in touch. That short placement left a lasting imprint on all of them, and reinforced the idea that even brief moments of care can make a lifelong difference.

Support, training and a wider network around the family

Carl and Jackie are clear that they don‚Äôt do this alone. They see themselves as the ‚Äúfront runners‚Äù ‚Äì the ones there day in, day out ‚Äì but they know there is a strong team behind them.

They have:

  • A supervising social worker who visits regularly and knows the children well
  • Children‚Äôs social workers who meet with the young people and listen to their views
  • Senior staff they can turn to when extra support is needed
  • Admin and office staff who are a ‚Äúfont of knowledge‚Äù when anything practical crops up

On top of that, they take part in training ‚Äì both mandatory courses and flexible online or in-person sessions ‚Äì and value learning from other foster parents over a cup of tea as much as from formal modules. Fosterplus provides a blended programme of training and support so families like Carl and Jackie‚Äôs never feel they are managing on their own.

They also offer short breaks (respite), welcoming other foster children into their home for weekends or holidays. It gives other carers a breather, and gives their own foster children the chance to meet children and share experiences.

‚ÄúWe did it together‚Äù

When Carl and Jackie think about the future, they imagine their foster children as adults, returning for visits, sharing news of jobs, homes and families of their own.

They hope those young people will look back and say, ‚ÄúWe did it together.‚Äù That they‚Äôll remember a home where siblings stayed side by side, where they were listened to, where there was space for both laughter and tears ‚Äì and where they always felt they had a place.

For Carl and Jackie, fostering has been challenging, emotional and eye-opening. It has also been deeply rewarding.

‚ÄúIf you can make a difference for even one child,‚Äù Carl says, ‚Äúit‚Äôs worth it.‚Äù

items.title: Helping Carers Shine: How Capstone Strengthens Every Fostering Journey
Why it‚Äôs the Right Time to Start Fostering
items.snippet: Fostering a child is a life-changing role that can seem like a big step to take. These six new reasons reveal why it's the perfect time to become a foster parent. The post Why it‚Äôs the Right Time to Start Fostering appeared first on Fosterplus.
items.content:
Want to make a difference this year by helping children in care? Many people have thought about starting a career where they can make a difference, and one of the most fulfilling paths you can take is to become a foster carer.

Fostering can often feel like a huge decision with many factors to consider. Weighing up a desire to help vulnerable children against personal commitments and‚ÄØfinancial pressures may create hesitation for people thinking of applying.

However, there has never been a better or more important time to consider starting a career in fostering. From a shortage of foster families to job satisfaction, let‚Äôs take a look at six reasons why you should become a foster carer in 2026.

6 Reasons to start fostering in 2026

Shortage of foster families

There is a national shortage of foster carers able to offer a safe and loving home to children in need. In 2023, there were approximately 107,000 looked-after children in the UK, an 8% increase over a period of five years.

If you have a spare room and feel you could foster a child or young person, then you‚Äôre needed more than ever to step forward and help make a difference to the lives of vulnerable children.

Generous fostering allowances and benefits

Financial concerns shouldn‚Äôt affect your ability to help children in care. We have all felt the pinch of recent cost-of-living struggles, which have placed finances at the forefront of people‚Äôs minds. Although money isn‚Äôt the main consideration when thinking about fostering, foster parents do receive generous payments for looking after children.

In recognition of the valuable work and dedication of our foster carers, we offer a generous fostering allowance and benefits package. Approved foster carers at Fosterplus receive an allowance between ¬£20,187 and ¬£25,749 per child, per year. This amount is generally tax-free and won‚Äôt affect any benefits you receive.

Additional benefits and allowances for things such as birthdays, holidays and celebrations are also included. This way, children in your care can enjoy these special occasions without added financial pressure.

Our allowances and perks mean more people are able to consider‚ÄØbecoming a foster parent, and it is a great time to take on this rewarding role, while also being paid generously for it.

New tax cut for foster carers

Alongside a generous foster care allowance, the government adjust the tax-free amount of qualifying care relief each April that foster carers are able to claim. For the 2025/2026 tax year, this was increased to a fixed amount of ¬£19,690. Weekly amounts are also allowed for carers per child, with ¬£415 per week for children under 11 and ¬£495 per week for children aged 11 or over.

This additional tax relief for foster carers means that families will now receive the majority ‚Äì if not all ‚Äì of their‚ÄØfostering allowance‚ÄØwithout paying any tax. If you‚Äôve been concerned about affording to foster, then this exciting update will be a significant benefit to your household finances.

Family networks

Creating family networks is another positive reason to start fostering in 2026. The connections you will gain, not only with our social work teams but also with other families who foster, make fostering and helping children in care a worthwhile thing to do.

We have a large‚ÄØsupportive network, regular events and support groups, as well as social get-togethers to suit everyone, so that you can connect with like-minded families and build lifelong friendships.

If you have your own birth children, you will see them build relationships, gain confidence, and benefit from a new experience and view of the world. Family and connection are what it‚Äôs all about, and it‚Äôs certainly something that foster care can offer.

Flexibility to suit your family

Did you know that around 1 in 3 UK employees are unhappy in their jobs?

A number of careers are seeing more pressure, such as NHS workers, nursing and teaching staff. Roles like these provide fantastic experience, and many people are now choosing to apply their transferable skills to fostering.

As a foster parent, you get to work flexibly from home. With the various types of foster care‚ÄØavailable, ranging from one day to several years, and our careful matching process, each fostering experience is unique and planned to suit your family.

Many people continue to‚ÄØwork alongside fostering,‚ÄØand with new flexibility in the workplace, it is something that has now become more achievable. In terms of income, there is a great opportunity to feel more financially secure while working and fostering.

Job satisfaction

Some of the main factors that people consider when looking for a new profession are job fulfilment, flexibility and good colleagues. These are some of the key benefits that you can expect when choosing to foster. If you are looking for a job that will have an impact and ‚Äògive back‚Äô to society, then fostering a child will be a worthwhile and rewarding vocation.

Fostering is one of the most fulfilling careers you can have, and foster parents often state that the main reason they chose this profession was the chance to make a difference.

Who can foster?

We welcome people from all backgrounds ‚Äì your culture, religion, marital status or sexual orientation won’t prevent you from fostering. You don‚Äôt need any specific qualifications, or even experience, as full training is provided.‚ÄØThe only initial requirements are:

  • You are aged over 21
  • You have the legal right to live and work in the UK
  • You have a spare room available for a child

Start fostering in 2026 to really make a difference this year by helping those in need.

If you‚Äôre looking for a rewarding career with amazing benefits and would like to learn more about becoming a foster parent,‚ÄØget in touch with us today.
