items.title: Children of Foster Carers ‚Äì Summer‚Äôs Story
items.snippet: Swiis welcomes foster carers from all walks of life, including those who already have children of their own. For some families, this means their child has spent most of their life as an only child, until the family decides to welcome foster children into their home. The post Children of Foster Carers ‚Äì Summer‚Äôs Story appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
Swiis welcomes foster carers from all walks of life, including those who already have children of their own. For some families, this means their child has spent most of their life as an only child, until the family decides to welcome foster children into their home.

This was the case for Summer, who grew up as an only child for 13 years before her parents began fostering two girls, aged 1 and 12 at the time. While the transition from being an only child to suddenly having other children in the household can be a big adjustment, Summer embraced the change and quickly thrived in her new role as the oldest child in the family.

Like any change in routine, fostering comes with challenges that the whole family must navigate. But for Summer, the rewards far outweigh the difficulties. 

‚ÄúI have a few things that I enjoy about us being a foster family. I love that there is always someone to spend time with and chat with. I also really like that when we became a foster family, Dad started spending more time at home because he left his old job, and now I get to see both Mum and Dad all the time, which is really nice.

‚ÄúI like that we are a bigger family now. When our house and my Auntie‚Äôs house get together, there are over ten of us. We used to just be three, but now we are five, and I really like that.

‚ÄúI also like that we all share things and help each other. For example, J played with my rabbit, Princess, last week, and while she was with her, she cleaned her out, which I was really happy about because that‚Äôs usually my job. In return, I helped J organise her wardrobe. We just do everything together.‚Äù

Over the past couple of years, Summer‚Äôs relationship with the foster children has blossomed, and together they have already created so many memorable experiences.

‚ÄúMy favourite thing we have experienced together is our holiday. We have had so many amazing times, but without a doubt, going to the Caribbean as a family was my favourite. The things I took for granted on holiday, they were just so excited about, and I really enjoyed sharing those moments with them. Plus, every time we wanted to play in the pool, there was always someone to play with.

‚ÄúThings like the plane ride stood out to me. I moaned about being on the plane for 9 hours, but they were so excited and grateful for just getting the opportunity to go on the plane.

‚ÄúWe also went zip-lining through the Caribbean Lake Park, which was really special. That is one of my favourite memories ever.‚Äù

As Summer‚Äôs relationships with the children have grown, her role within the household has changed, and she has taken on more responsibilities as the oldest child. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs great how my responsibilities have changed! I used to have the jobs of dishwasher and recycling, but now J does the dishwasher, and I do the recycling, so we have split the jobs, which is good because I didn‚Äôt like the dishwasher, but J doesn‚Äôt mind it.

‚ÄúI am the oldest now, so I do older sister stuff, like reminding P to put her coat on and trying to teach her how to fasten her shoelaces. I also taught J how to straighten and curl her hair.‚Äù

As Summer has taken on new responsibilities at home, she has also had time to reflect on how fostering has shaped her life and how it might influence her future. When asked if there was anything else she would like to share about her experiences, Summer said:

‚ÄúFostering has been in my life since I was really young. I was 6 or 7 when Auntie started, and then 12 when Mum and Dad started, so I am pretty used to the fostering world now. Since we started fostering, we have had really good days, but also some really difficult days. Everyone tells us ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a journey‚Äô, but that‚Äôs because it actually is.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm really happy with where we are now though, life‚Äôs normal for us. I feel really proud that we foster, and I have even started thinking about becoming a foster carer myself when I‚Äôm older. I‚Äôm going to finish Uni and get my degree, but I really do think I will take a similar path and foster. I want to foster teens. Seeing how J opened up to me when we chatted, I think I‚Äôd be good with teens.‚Äù

Summer‚Äôs inspiring story of growing up as the child of foster carers highlights the incredible experiences and memories that fostering has given her, as well as how it has influenced her future. Fostering can be a life-changing experience for everyone involved, not just the children and young people in care, but for the entire family.

items.title: 5 Tips to Remember When Feeling Overwhelmed as a Foster Parent
items.snippet: No matter how experienced you are, fostering can feel overwhelming at times. In this blog, we explore common causes of overwhelm for foster parents, how to recognise the signs, and five supportive, practical tips to help you manage stress and get back to feeling more balanced and in control. The post 5 Tips to Remember When Feeling Overwhelmed as a Foster Parent appeared first on Orange Grove Foster Care.
items.content:
As a foster parent, regardless of whether you‚Äôve been fostering one month or five years, at some point on your journey, you may feel overwhelmed. From taking on too much and holding yourself to unrealistic standards to unexpected life events and crises that turn your day-to-day life into chaos, overwhelm can happen for various reasons.

The real question is, what do you do when you feel overwhelmed? In this article, we explore why overwhelm happens, symptoms you may experience, and tips to help you manage when your plate feels too full.

Why overwhelm happens in fostering

 

Fostering is rewarding but challenging

One of the best things about fostering is that it isn‚Äôt your typical nine-to-five job. No two days are ever the same ‚Äì your role is constantly evolving, and you make a difference in the lives of children in your care every single day.

That being said, fostering is a 24/7 role, which means you can‚Äôt just clock out and switch off from your responsibilities at 5 pm. Between attending meetings and appointments, school runs, managing household tasks, and finding time for yourself, you can quickly begin to feel stretched without careful planning.

There may also be times when you feel like everything is under control, until something unexpected happens, such as a family member falling ill, and suddenly everything feels too much.

Overwhelm and mental health¬†¬†

Overwhelm can have a profound impact on your mental health, triggering conditions like anxiety and depression and leading to fatigue, irritability, or feeling trapped. There are also physical symptoms of feeling overwhelmed, such as headaches, nausea, sleep disturbances and changes in eating habits.¬†¬†

The good news is that feeling overwhelmed isn‚Äôt something you have to put up with; there are steps you can take to lighten your load and help you begin feeling like yourself again.

Tips on what to do if you feel overwhelmed

When things are running smoothly, feeling overwhelmed can seem like something that only happens to other people. But the truth is, it can happen to anyone at any time. That’s why it’s so important to have a few strategies you can turn to when things start to feel too much. Here are our top tips for coping when life feels overwhelming.

  1. Write everything down

    When you‚Äôre stretched beyond capacity, one of the best things you can do to help yourself is to write down everything that‚Äôs on your mind. It doesn‚Äôt need to be in any particular order or even make any sense, but brain dumping everything onto a piece of paper can help lift the weight from your mind.

    Once it‚Äôs written down, you can start prioritising, organising and regaining a sense of control. For example, you could split tasks into categories like ‘To Do Now,’ ‘To Do Tomorrow,’ and ‘Can Wait Until Later’ so you can tackle things one step at a time, rather than trying to think about everything all at once.

  2. Take a step back

    When everything feels too much, feelings of failure can begin to creep in, especially if you‚Äôre overwhelmed by a situation you‚Äôre facing with the child in your care. In moments like these, it‚Äôs vital to take a step back and look at the bigger picture.

    Yes, you might be finding a particular behaviour or scenario tricky, but when you take time to reflect, you‚Äôll see how far you and the child in your care have actually come.

    It‚Äôs also important to remind yourself that you’re not alone; everyone feels overwhelmed sometimes. It isn‚Äôt a sign of failure ‚Äì if anything, it‚Äôs a sign that you’re giving so much of yourself that you’ve forgotten you matter too

  3. Don‚Äôt ignore your mental health

    When things feel hard, caring for your mental health becomes even more important. Whether it‚Äôs taking a walk in the park, watching rubbish TV, or eating your favourite food, do whatever helps bring you a bit of peace, even if just for half an hour.

    During difficult times, it‚Äôs also crucial to be mindful about what you‚Äôre viewing online. If you enjoy scrolling through social media or checking up on the news, when you‚Äôre already feeling overwhelmed, absorbing the chaos of the world can actually make things worse. Instead, opt for some light-hearted reels or find other activities that soothe your mind. We have a few ideas in our ultimate self-care guide.

  4. Set realistic expectations

    Goals are good, they drive us forward, keep us focused, and give us purpose ‚Äì but only if they‚Äôre realistic. Unrealistic goals can leave you feeling overwhelmed and defeated, especially if they feel impossible to reach.

    Remember, the main goal of a foster parent is to provide a safe, stable and nurturing home that helps children and young people achieve the best possible outcomes. But when you foster a child living with trauma, healing and progress take time.

    Set small goals and celebrate when you reach them. For example, they could be as simple as encouraging the child in your care to brush their teeth, do their homework on time, or eat a banana. These little achievements are likely more significant than you realise, and can remind you that you are having a positive impact when you’re feeling overwhelmed.

  5. You‚Äôre not a robot

    Sometimes you have to remind yourself that you’re only human, you‚Äôre not a robot, and your capacity for mental stress is not unlimited. There may be times on your fostering journey where you need to take a break, and that‚Äôs exactly why we offer respite foster care.

    Caring for a child living with trauma can be challenging, and asking to take a break is a lot better than throwing in the towel because you‚Äôre feeling overwhelmed. Sometimes all you need is a little time to yourself to be with your own thoughts and do your own thing, so you feel rested and ready to take on the next challenge.

    Respite isn‚Äôt selfish; taking care of yourself ensures you‚Äôre in the right frame of mind to continue providing the best possible care.

Remember: You‚Äôre never alone¬†

When you foster with Orange Grove, you‚Äôre never alone on your fostering journey. We‚Äôre here to help you every step of the way by providing support for your whole family, which includes:¬†¬†

  • Dedicated social worker: Whether you need advice or just a listening ear, your supervising social worker is available whenever you need them.¬†
  • Family support worker: Our family support workers ensure everyone in the foster home feels valued, heard, and included.¬†¬†
  • Education experts: Feeling overwhelmed by your foster child‚Äôs education? Our education experts are on hand to provide guidance to help you support them in getting the most out of their education.¬†¬†
  • Therapist: Sometimes you need a safe space to offload, and that‚Äôs why we give all our foster parents access to a therapist whenever needed.¬†¬†
  • 24/7 helpline: Your role isn‚Äôt nine till five, and neither is our support. Our helpline is available for you 24/7.¬†¬†
  • Support groups: Our regular local support groups help you meet other foster parents, share experiences, and build a wider network of support.¬†¬†
  • Paid respite: If you do need a break, we offer up to two weeks of paid respite care.¬†

¬†

Start your fostering journey today¬†¬†

Ready to switch to a more meaningful vocation? Start your fostering journey today by calling us on 0800 369 8513 or by completing our online enquiry form.¬†

You can also join us at one of our weekly virtual information sessions where you‚Äôll learn everything there is to know about fostering, including fostering allowances, types of fostering, how the application process works and more.¬†

items.title: Black History Month: Recognising the needs of black children in care in the UK
items.snippet: Black History Month is a time to celebrate culture, pride, and progress. At Fosterplus, it's also a time to reflect on how we support Black children in care - uplifting their heritage, listening to their experiences, and recognising the unique challenges they may face in the UK foster care system. The post Black History Month: Recognising the needs of black children in care in the UK appeared first on Fosterplus.
items.content:
This month in the UK, we‚Äôre celebrating Black History Month. This year‚Äôs theme is ‚ÄòStanding Firm in Power and Pride,‚Äô highlighting the incredible contributions of black communities across the UK. ¬†

Black History Month is an excellent opportunity to celebrate those who have come before, pay homage to the incredible work of activists and highlight the need to keep fighting prejudice when it arises.¬†Let‚Äôs take a look at some of the ways in which we work to uplift children‚Äôs heritage here at Fosterplus and recognise the unique needs of black children in care.

Why do we need more black foster parents?

In the UK, recent data shows that children from black or multiracial backgrounds are overly represented within the care system, making up an estimated 17% of children in care. At the same time, we also have a shortage of black foster carers.¬†¬†

Of course, foster parents from any background can do an amazing job at meeting children‚Äôs cultural needs while caring for a child of a different race, but it‚Äôs generally accepted that children experience the best outcomes and are able to transition more easily when they are matched with families who share their identity, whether that be their culture, ethnicity, or sharing a language. This helps children to deepen their sense of identity and also helps their foster family‚Äôs house to feel¬†more like home‚Äî whether that‚Äôs something big, like sharing a religion and observing the same daily faith-based routines, to the smaller things, like a child‚Äôs favourite meal making a regular appearance on the family dinner table.¬†¬†

Cultural matching can be especially important for children who have travelled alone to the UK seeing asylum. Interested in learning more about how foster care can support sanctuary-seeking children? Read Aki‚Äôs story of coming to the UK from Eritrea, and how he learned to feel at home with his foster family.¬†

 

Combatting the risks of adultification for black children in care

Another unique challenge faced by black and non-white children in care is the risk of adultification. On average, children from non-white backgrounds enter care at an older age than white children, who make up the majority of children in care in the UK.¬†¬†

The Independent Office for Police Conduct has identified that black children are at an increased risk of experiencing adultification compared to other groups. Adultification is a type of racial bias which assumes that a child is somehow less innocent, more mature or more responsible than they really are, leading to children being treated as though they were adults. This can be harmful in many ways, including the risk that Police and law enforcement will stereotype children with black heritage, or assign adult motives to them. Another element of adultification particularly impacts black girls, that being the sexualisation of black girls which can lead to authorities putting blame on them as victims for the abuse they suffer at the hands of predatory adults.¬†

Social worker and lecturer Nana Yabbey-Hagan gave some great insight into where adultification rears its head among professionals on an episode of The Social Worker & The Mentor Podcast. He said:¬†

‚ÄòI’m a black male social worker and I‚Äôve heard the language and the rhetoric of professionals, how they’re describing [black children], and I’ve had to step in and say to them, I’m quite offended by how you’re describing this child or young person. There’s a duty of care that you have regardless of [race], and what you’re doing is not taking into account the vulnerabilities of this child.‚Äô¬†

‚ÄòThe question has to be if that child in front of you was not a black child, would you be using the same language? That’s the reason why in our community you find that a lot of black families [engaging with child services] don’t trust the professionals because they feel that there’s a level of inequality and discrimination that’s at work, and that professionals have a certain view of children who are black and won’t give them the level of care they should have in comparison to their white counterparts.‚Äô¬†

As Nana says, adultification can be both subtle or advert, and is something which professionals working with children must learn to address and combat. Read on to find out how we work to support children and families here at Fosterplus.¬†¬†

How we support children and families¬†

  • Staff training. Every staff member at Fosterplus, from our over-the-phone advisors to our supervising social workers, receives regular training on diversity, inclusion, and cultural awareness to help support our children and families and avoid bias.¬†¬†
  • Proper training for foster parents. We offer advanced learning modules on topics such as adultification, cultural awareness and caring for a child with a different racial background to ensure that foster parents caring for children of a different ethnicity know how to fully meet their needs. This includes teaching foster parents about the importance of learning how to properly care for black hair and skin.¬†¬†
  • Support for black children in care. At Fosterplus we offer a range of support for children which includes ensuring careful matching, our support groups for children and a range of online resources.¬†¬†
  • Support for foster parents. We offer culturally-based support for our foster parents, for example our regular coffee mornings for Eritrean families. Along with our 24/7 phone support and the support of your own Supervising Social Worker, well always be right by your side when you need us.¬†¬†

Further reading foster parents

Having cultural awareness is an essential part of a foster parent‚Äôs role. If you feel unsure about discussing ethnicity and culture with your foster children, gaining a deeper understanding of these topics by doing additional research is a fantastic place to start. We recommend these brilliant resources by black creators:¬†

  • This episode of The Social Worker & The Mentor Podcast gives viewers excellent insight into adultification bias in the care sector. Hosts Robert and Nana have an honest, down-to-earth conversation about adultification, cultural competence and racism against children within the care sector.¬†¬†
  • This article by Tonjie Reece, founder of the gender-based violence prevention charity eleven24, looks into the particular risks which black girls face as a consequence of adultification, and explores the intersection between racism and sexism against girls and women, known as ‚ÄòMisogynoir.‚Äô¬†
  • ‚ÄòWhy Are All the Black Kids Sitting Together in the Cafeteria?‚Äô by Beverly Daniel Tatum is an American text which explores racial identity and the importance of being open to having conversations about race.¬†¬†¬†

¬†

Reading books or watching TV together as a family can also bring up plenty of opportunities to ask questions, discuss our feelings and share our experiences. These resources are great picks to enjoy with your foster children:¬†

  • ‚ÄòThe Skin You Live In‚Äô by Michael Tyler is a lovely book for young children which celebrates diversity. It‚Äôs a great bedtime read which can prompt conversations with your little one about self-love and celebrating our differences.¬†¬†
  • ‚ÄòBlack and British: A Forgotten History‚Äô by David Olusoga gives readers an insightful look into the rich history of black communities in the UK. There‚Äôs also a TV documentary series available for free on BBC iPlayer which delves into Olusoga‚Äôs research which could make a great watch with your foster teen.¬†¬†

¬†

Making a difference every day¬†

Each year we highlight the unique needs of black children in care during October, but issues such as adultification and the need for more black and ethnic minority foster parents impact children all year round. If you‚Äôre ready to learn more about how you could make a difference by fostering a child, discover how you could begin a career in fostering with Fosterplus today by getting in touch with our team via our online enquiry form.¬†

items.title: Children of Foster Carers ‚Äì Harmeet‚Äôs Story
items.snippet: When a family begins their fostering journey, it does not just impact the foster carers themselves, it affects everyone connected to the household, including their children. The post Children of Foster Carers ‚Äì Harmeet‚Äôs Story appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
When a family begins their fostering journey, it does not just impact the foster carers themselves, it affects everyone connected to the household, including their children. For many children of foster carers, it means learning to share their home, toys and even their parents’ time, but for those older children who are now adults no longer living at home, fostering impacts them differently.

This has been the case for Harmeet, as when her parents decided to foster, she was no longer living in the family household, but she still experienced the rewards of fostering and found ways to support her parents and the children in their care.

‚ÄúSeeing a foster child feeling safe and happy at home is rewarding because we are able to work together and provide a stable and caring environment. Even though I don‚Äôt live at home, I support my parents by helping care for the children when they are away for the day. It‚Äôs meaningful to be part of that support system and contribute in any way I can.‚Äù

Fostering brings many new responsibilities, and it is not only the foster carers themselves who have a change in responsibility, but also everyone close to them who plays a part in supporting the journey. For Harmeet, she has played a massive part in supporting her parents with the children and young people they foster, and it has taught her valuable emotional and interpersonal skills.

‚ÄúMy responsibilities have changed since my parents began fostering. Even though I no longer live at home, I now help more with caring for the foster children when I visit or when my parents are out for the day.

‚ÄúI might play with them, help with meals, or just keep them company so they feel safe and supported. It has taught me the importance of consistency and patience, and I feel proud to be part of something that really makes a difference.‚Äù

Over the years that Harmeet‚Äôs parents have fostered, she has built many wonderful memories with the children and young people who have joined their family. Each new arrival has brought new experiences, and Harmeet continues to form special bonds with all the children her parents look after, making a lasting impact on her.

‚ÄúOne of the most memorable experiences I had was with a foster child who came into our home at the age of 3. From the beginning, we built a strong and positive bond. I enjoyed getting her small toys and gifts, which always brought her joy. Although I no longer see her in person as often, we stay connected through regular video calls. She lights up with excitement every time we talk, and seeing that joy reminds me how meaningful even the smallest connections can be in a child‚Äôs life.‚Äù

Harmeet‚Äôs story highlights that even when a child of foster carers is an adult and no longer living in the family home, they can still be deeply impacted by the rewarding experiences that fostering brings. It has given Harmeet a new perspective on responsibility and shown her just how meaningful fostering can be in a child or young person‚Äôs life.

items.title: Children of Foster Carers ‚Äì Rachel‚Äôs Story
items.snippet: Being a child of a foster carer can open a world of new experiences and shape your life in ways you might never expect. The post Children of Foster Carers ‚Äì Rachel‚Äôs Story appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
Being a child of a foster carer can open a world of new experiences and shape your life in ways you might never expect. For Rachel, this allowed her to witness firsthand the impact that care, support, and guidance can have on a child‚Äôs life. Rachel’s mother’s decision to foster not only shaped the dynamics of their family but also inspired Rachel‚Äôs own path in life, leading her to become a foster carer herself.

Rachel has always believed that the rewards of welcoming foster children into her household far outweigh any challenges. For her, the addition of foster children and young people felt natural, and a lot of her daily life remained the same.

‚ÄúHaving foster children was great, it was like inviting our ‚Äòbonus family‚Äô into our home. We extended our family to those who need it most and seeing them grow and progress into young adults is one of the most rewarding things I have experienced.

‚ÄúI also don‚Äôt feel anything changed when we gained our bonus family. We made sure they felt safe and secure, but we lived our lives as normal with our new additions.‚Äù

During the years of being a child of a foster carer, Rachel was part of countless special memories that ranged from small, everyday moments to life-changing events. From playful afternoons in the garden to the celebrations of important milestones, these experiences left a lasting impression on her.

‚ÄúOver the time that my mother was a foster carer, we had many memorable experiences, so it’s hard to choose one! I remember setting up a water slide in our garden on a summer’s day, which ended up in a big water fight with lots of laughs! We have shared memories on holidays, life celebrations, and milestones. One of the biggest highlights was when we had the honour of reuniting a child with her mother after around 10 years of separation. It brought tears to everyone‚Äôs eyes. What an amazing moment to be a part of!‚Äù

The impact of fostering as a child of a foster carer stayed with Rachel, and today she has followed in her mother‚Äôs footsteps, becoming a foster carer herself, which Rachel would encourage all to try if they can.

‚ÄúI would like to add that if anyone is considering fostering but unsure due to their birth children, in my experience, it added a level of gratitude, empathy, and love that I wouldn‚Äôt have experienced if my mother didn‚Äôt foster. Seeing those children grow to the amazing individuals they are today encouraged me to become a foster carer myself. I have now been doing this for almost three years, and I‚Äôve enjoyed it from day one.

‚ÄúGive it a go and change some lives!‚Äù

items.title: What makes a good foster carer?
‚ÄúEveryone touches my heart in their own special way.‚Äù
items.snippet: Trina became a foster carer when her son was 9 years old. She highlights that fostering is about the 'tiny little steps'. The post ‚ÄúEveryone touches my heart in their own special way.‚Äù appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
“Everyone touches my heart in their own special way.”

  • Home
  • Articles
  • “Everyone touches my heart in their own special way.”

Trina was helping out at a school, when one of the teachers recommended fostering to her. She decided to look into it. She’s now been a TACT foster carer for 17 years.

Many years ago I was helping out in the local school, and one of the teachers was a TACT foster carer and she kept saying to me ‚Äòyou could do this – the way you are with children‚Äô. So it was actually one of the school teachers that got me into this.

So I gave TACT a call, hoping that they were going to take me seriously – and I’m still here 17 years later.

You can foster as a family

When I did look into [fostering] further, we only had my son Ben at home at the time ‚Äì the other three had left. Ben was 9 when I first started to look into it, and by the time TACT had come out and done all their investigations, and I’d done the Skills to Foster course – we actually became foster carers when our own son was 10.

Ben’s always grown up around other foster children because his best friends in school were twins and they were both fostered. So he understood the fostering side of looking after children. He actually just thrived with the six year old little boy. They both had the same interests – it just worked really well.  I don’t think Ben ever had his face put out of joint because this isn’t my adventure, this is our family adventure.

TACT always do a yearly annual summer trip and things like that, then they do the Christmas parties and discos. One year we actually did Disneyland, Paris – so my own son actually came along and joined in on that as well.

“I just love what I do and seeing that little difference – you don’t have to see a huge difference you know, just tiny little steps. I just think it’s amazing. I can tell you I’ve got the best job in the world.”

Trina, TACT foster carer since 2009

Everyone touches my heart

Everyone touches my heart in their own special way. We had a little boy at the age of two. We were told that he was unadoptable. With a lot of therapeutic work, a lot of play and giving him 100% time and effort he got adopted 18 months later. I still get messages and I still see how he’s doing. He sends me Christmas cards and Mother’s Day cards, so to me that is an absolute success story. He’s actually been adopted now for six years, so all through those six years I’ve had all contact with him

I just love what I do and seeing that little difference – you don’t have to see a huge difference you know, just tiny little steps. I just think it’s amazing. I can tell you I’ve got the best job in the world, and I work for the best people as well.

items.title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about supporting them in whatever it is they want to do‚Äù
items.snippet: TACT foster carer, Aileen, talks about keeping her young people safe and supporting them in whatever they want to do in life. The post ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about supporting them in whatever it is they want to do‚Äù appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
“It‚Äôs about supporting them in whatever it is they want to do”

  • Home
  • Articles
  • “It‚Äôs about supporting them in whatever it is they want to do”

Aileen learned a lot from the young people in her care; from arts and crafts right through to adjusting expectations to be in line with the needs of her young people.

My favourite thing about being a foster carer is watching young people develop from sometimes a frightened young person, or a young person who is unsure of where they are going, into blossoming young adults who go to university or college or get an apprenticeship.

My last young man who got himself into little bit of bother: we’ve now got him in the Princes’ Trust learning a trade. It’s about being positive, not looking at everything that’s negative and helping them to develop confidence in their own abilities, so they can move on and realise that they can do things.

The support from TACT has been superb. I have the finest Supervising Social Worker that any person could ever have. She is absolutely brilliant.

Encouraging a hobby

My young lady [who I was providing care for] did some artwork. She was very keen on arts and crafts. I have a friend who does lots of art and crafts, and she runs classes. So I went along [with my young person]. I wasn‚Äôt very good at it, but she was brilliant. I went so that she would gain confidence. People could see how good she was. I learned a lot about colours and that, while I was there.

I encourage all my young people to do things. A young person wanted to learn to swim, so I made sure she learned to swim. I try to find out what their hobbies are and then encourage them to do it. It just means sometimes having to take them places and then picking them up.

‚ÄúI encourage all my young people to do things. A young person wanted to learn to swim, so I made sure she learned to swim. I try to find out what their hobbies are and then encourage them to do it.”

Aileen, TACT foster carer since 2014

If they feel safe, they can thrive

Another thing that I think is very important for [potential] foster carers to understand is that young people will go out, especially if they’re teenagers. They will miss the bus back so the most important thing is that they know that they can phone you. I always have a place of safety, usually it‚Äôs Sainsbury’s supermarket or somewhere where they can wait for me.

The advice I would give is that you’ve got to accept the ups and downs. There is going to be trials and tribulations. They trust you, they’ve got faith in you and they’re looking to you to help them. Be to be patient and help them to feel secure.

I’ve always had lots of ambition for my young people. I try very hard to instil ambition into them, but I have learned that some young people are just happy doing something different – they don’t all want to go to university. So I have learnt to look a little bit more at the needs of a young person, rather than my ambition for them. It‚Äôs about supporting them in whatever it is they want to do.

A highlight of mine has been a young lady who actually was determined she wasn’t going to be staying in the care system – but actually stayed for four years and then said ‚ÄòI would have made the biggest mistake of my life if I had left‚Äô. I watched her grow from a frightened little girl who had been thrown out of a family home with nothing and nobody, into a Deputy Manager at a store. When I see her in the store I sometimes look at that young lady, and I remember a 12 year old girl who was terrified.

items.title: TACT ‚ÄòKicks Off‚Äô with Dundee United Banner
items.snippet: TACT Scotland have taken the first step to making a connection with Dundee United, in the hope of keying in to their Community Trust Charity. The post TACT ‚ÄòKicks Off‚Äô with Dundee United Banner appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
TACT ‘Kicks Off’ with Dundee United Banner

  • Home
  • News

TACT Scotland have taken an exciting first step towards building a connection with Dundee United.

No, we‚Äôre not talking about the TACT team pulling on the club‚Äôs iconic orange strip and stepping onto the pitch ‚Äì although we suspect a few of our staff might secretly fancy themselves as the club’s star strikers!

Instead, we‚Äôre proud to announce the installation of a brand new pitch-side banner carrying the simple yet powerful message, ‚Äòcould you be a foster carer?‚Äô The banner is part of a wider effort to encourage more diverse members of the public to consider fostering, along with dispelling myths that foster carers need to be superhuman or possess exceptional skills or qualifications in order to make a difference.

However, the hope is to get more involved in the Dundee United Community Trust, a charity set up to help improve the lives of people in Dundee and the surrounding areas. The trust was set up in 2017, and has so far managed to invest over ¬£1.3 million into the local community.

As a charity focused on providing safe, nurturing foster homes and supporting care-experienced children, young people, and adults, we are always seeking ways to engage with like-minded organisations.

items.title: Orange Grove Foster Parents Named Finalists at the National Children & Young People Awards
items.snippet: Foster carers Amanda and David Eyeington have been shortlisted for the Foster Carer Award at this year‚Äôs National Children & Young People Awards, recognising their outstanding dedication and care. The post Orange Grove Foster Parents Named Finalists at the National Children & Young People Awards appeared first on Orange Grove Foster Care.
items.content:
Orange Grove is proud to celebrate the achievements of foster carers Amanda and David Eyeington, who have been named finalists in the Foster Carer Award at this year‚Äôs National Children & Young People (CYP) Awards.

The National CYP Awards are a prestigious annual event that celebrates excellence across children‚Äôs services, recognising individuals and teams who make a remarkable difference to the lives of children, young people, and families. From social workers and care teams to foster carers and support staff, the awards shine a spotlight on those who go above and beyond in their roles.

 

Amanda and David‚Äôs dedication, compassion, and tireless advocacy for children have earned them national recognition, with the winners to be announced at the awards ceremony in Birmingham on Friday 3 October 2025.

The couple, who have been fostering with Orange Grove since 2011, are shortlisted for the Foster Carer Award. This category honours foster carers who demonstrate perseverance, advocacy, and an unwavering commitment to placing the needs of children at the centre of their care.

Over the last 14 years, Amanda and David have provided a safe and nurturing home for many children, consistently going above and beyond to ensure every child feels valued and supported. Their dedication extends beyond fostering placements, with the couple maintaining relationships with families long after children have moved on, reflecting the depth of care they bring to their role.

A shining example of their approach is seen in the long-term placement of a young boy with Down‚Äôs Syndrome. Amanda and David not only provide him with consistent, loving care, but also work tirelessly to maintain his connection with his mum and siblings. From organising family visits and sharing holiday photos, to supporting milestone events and everyday celebrations, the Eyeingtons ensure he enjoys a strong sense of belonging in both his foster and birth family.

Their commitment to advocacy is also evident in education. When the young boy faced barriers at school, Amanda championed his right to use adaptive technology so he could take part fully alongside his peers. Their efforts have helped him grow in confidence and develop his communication skills, moving from single words to fuller sentences.

In addition to their direct care, Amanda and David play an active role in supporting the wider fostering community. They regularly provide advice and respite to fellow carers, and Amanda leads a Downs Syndrome support group in Milton Keynes to help families and carers share resources and experiences.

Reflecting on their impact, their supervising team describe the couple as ‚Äúvalued members of the Orange Grove family whose dedication and advocacy have created life-changing outcomes for children.‚Äù

Orange Grove is immensely proud to see Amanda and David‚Äôs commitment recognised on a national stage and wish them the very best at the awards ceremony in Birmingham this October.

The post Orange Grove Foster Parents Named Finalists at the National Children & Young People Awards¬† appeared first on Orange Grove Foster Care.

items.title: Ordinary People Making An Extraordinary Difference
items.snippet: Do you need to be extraordinary to foster, or is it something that is within the reach of all of us? We dispel 3 common myths and beliefs. The post Ordinary People Making An Extraordinary Difference appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
Ordinary People Making An Extraordinary Difference

  • Home
  • Articles
  • Ordinary People Making An Extraordinary Difference

Many people believe that foster carers must be superhuman. After all, it‚Äôs a role or a life choice that means that you open your home to young people who may have never experienced a nurturing and supportive home life. You provide care, guidance, help with school or finding a job. You‚Äôre a shoulder and a crutch when needed and are always there for them. You say the right things at the right times, are never wrong and can teleport anywhere in the country at will.

Now, that really would be superhuman.

Back in the real world, it‚Äôs hardly surprising that fostering can appear intimidating or out of reach for many people. They believe that they don‚Äôt possess the right level of skills or experience, or they think that they have to achieve life-changing outcomes for young people.

What many people don‚Äôt see are the foster carers who come from different vocational backgrounds, who are just regular, ordinary people who want to help and make a difference. The people who understand a young person‚Äôs needs and are able to make the smallest changes that have the potential to be game changing for a young person.

This is how ordinary people make extraordinary differences, and as a charitable fostering agency we see it happen every day with our teams of foster carers all over the UK.

So we want to highlight that you don‚Äôt need to be superhuman, that you don‚Äôt need to arrive bursting with childcare skills and experience, and by the very fact that you used to be a nurse, a bus driver, an accountant or a retail manager means that the life experience you bring will only ever augment your role as a foster carer.

Let‚Äôs look deeper at three areas that could dispel beliefs or myths that foster carers need to be superhuman to make an extraordinary difference:

1. Coming from different vocational backgrounds

Whilst there are some specialist types of foster care that may require previous experience of working with children with additional needs, most fostering types do not require any experience at all. This is because full training is provided.

But we can go one step further than that and say that diversity with regards to previous vocational experience is highly sought, and actually achieves two goals:

1) It makes fostering more accessible to those who don‚Äôt have sector experience and who want to make a difference to children‚Äôs lives.

2) It potentially creates wider matching opportunities due to foster carers bringing specific life skills and adjacent experiences to the role.

David used to be a bus driver but wanted to do something more fulfilling: ‚ÄúI was a bus driver. I hated it, but I just couldn‚Äôt find what I really wanted to do, so I just plodded on driving buses, and generally feeling unfulfilled. Then I saw an advertisement which posed the question: ‚ÄúCould you foster?‚Äù and I thought, yes, I probably could. And fortunately, fostering charity TACT Scotland agreed with me, which is why I am now a very proud and very fulfilled full-time dad of four children ‚Äì foster dad to three siblings, and dad to my birth son.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecoming a full-time foster carer has completed my life. When I look at the children playing together, I feel like my world has been opened up in a way that bus driving or most other jobs never could.‚Äù

David & Ruth, TACT foster carers since 2018

Sarah didn‚Äôt feel valued in her role as a retail manager: ‚ÄúI left a retail manager‚Äôs position in a food shop to pursue a different career as I didn‚Äôt feel valued in my current role. At the time, I wasn‚Äôt passionate about anything and lacked purpose. I decided I wanted to do something to give back to the community. Rich and I both felt fortunate to have grown up in a loving family and we wanted to give that to somebody who needed it, so we agreed to look into fostering.‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel valued and appreciated. We receive amazing support from TACT, especially [from] our Supervising Social Worker, and the Local Authority. We keep in touch with every child, and it is lovely to hear what they are up to.‚Äù

Sarah & Richard, TACT foster carers since 2016

2. Foster carers aren‚Äôt saviours, they are enablers

You may have heard fostering agencies or carers use the phrase ‚Äòmaking a difference‚Äô with regards to providing care for young people.

The reason why this phrase is used so often is twofold. Firstly it rightly avoids any unrealistic expectations; foster carers are not expected to swoop in and save the day (we have previously said that foster carers are not superhuman). They are there to make a difference to young people who have experienced varying degrees of past trauma.

This unpicking of current emotional responses caused by trauma experienced in the past is an evolutionary process involving a whole team around a child. A foster carer is not expected to ‚Äòsolve‚Äô issues experienced by young people, only to use their training along with specialist expertise from the support network around them, to commence a process of healing.

Another reason why making a difference is a chosen phrase is to highlight that a foster carer‚Äôs role is to enable young people to take control of their own lives, to discover new hobbies, to decide what they want to do as a career. Providing a nurturing and caring home environment, where young people can rebuild trust and regain confidence provides them with the tools to start making their own life choices.

By removing unrealistic expectations from the shoulders of foster carers, we can start to see the most important traits that are required of the role: the ability to provide a safe, nurturing and caring environment to enable young people to thrive and take control of their lives.

‚ÄúBy being a foster carer, you‚Äôre helping children to have an independent life and support them with the many challenges that they may encounter. It is very satisfying to know that you have helped them become more confident and it is rewarding knowing that your time with the young people has been of benefit to them. Sometimes there is trauma that needs to be addressed and that requires a lot of patience.‚Äù

Yasmin, TACT foster carer since 2020

3. The smallest gestures can bring the best outcomes

Many people believe that to make a difference to children‚Äôs lives, foster carers must take significant steps such as organising daily one-to-one time or encouraging participation in several outdoor hobbies.

In reality, it‚Äôs often the smallest gestures or simple actions that have the greatest impact.

It‚Äôs about understanding a young person‚Äôs needs, passions and interests and identifying small actions that will not be overwhelming to them, but that can still make a difference and reinforce their mental health and wellbeing.

This may sound complex, but it is relatively straightforward.

Alice and James, who have been fostering for TACT since 2022, talk about identifying a young person‚Äôs interests, and how this led them to arrange a specific event: ‚ÄúA highlight might be taking a musical-obsessed teenager who had never been to the theatre before to see Hamilton in London. You‚Äôve never heard someone scream so loud as when I gave her the tickets for Christmas!‚Äù

‚ÄúPeople often tell us we‚Äôre amazing for fostering and I‚Äôm never sure how to respond to that. It‚Äôs an amazing thing to do with your life but you don‚Äôt need any unusual skills ‚Äì you just need time and sticking-power to invest in a child who needs it.‚Äù

Alice & James, TACT foster carers since 2022

You don‚Äôt need to be extraordinary to foster

You don’t need to be extraordinary to be a foster carer. What matters most is providing a stable, supportive, and caring environment for a child. Many people mistakenly believe that foster carers must possess exceptional skills or qualifications, and be almost superhuman. But it‚Äôs the everyday qualities; patience, empathy, reliability, and a willingness to listen that make the biggest difference. Fostering is a learning journey, full of shared discoveries, growth and moments that will make the experience truly rewarding.

Children in care benefit most from genuine connections from someone who is present in their lives. Someone who offers encouragement and creates a safe space for them to thrive ‚Äì enabling them to eventually gain independence and to forge their own path in life.

You don‚Äôt need to be extraordinary to foster, but conversely the sum total of the everyday care, patience and empathy you provide to young people could make an extraordinary difference.

Start Your Fostering Journey. Make An Extraordinary Difference.

The post Ordinary People Making An Extraordinary Difference appeared first on TACT.

items.title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs putting in place what she never got when she was little‚Äù
items.snippet: TACT foster carer, Kate, talks about how she made a difference by providing opportunities to a young person that they'd never had before. The post ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs putting in place what she never got when she was little‚Äù appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
“It’s putting in place what she never got when she was little”

  • Home
  • Articles
  • “It’s putting in place what she never got when she was little”

Kate originally trained as a nursery nurse, but when she looked into fostering it ‚Äòjust clicked‚Äô.

My background is that I trained as a nursery nurse many years ago. Shortly after that I became a military wife and then I raised my own daughter.

One day a friend said to me “Do you know what, you should have a look at fostering.” And something clicked. So I decided to do a bit of research. That is basically what brought me to fostering.

The support from TACT East Midlands – it’s been spectacular. They’ve always been good, I‚Äôve felt they’ve always had my back – always been there when I needed them. But also, they’re a nice group of people. I’ve known them for a long time now.

A favourite memory

A favourite memory with a young person I provided care for is that she and I used to read Harry Potter out loud Harry Potter together. That was our thing. Sometimes we’d include the rest of the family and we’d have two copies of the same Harry Potter book. You’d start reading and you could stop at any point. The person who was there listening had to take over at exactly that point. So it’s a bit of a game!

It was a great fun, and the laughter that came out of that! It went on for a long time – for about three years. Everyday we used to read. It started with just a chapter and then we’d read for an hour. Her reading skills are much better. She can read for herself now, but sometimes we still do go back to Harry Potter and we read a few chapters out loud because it’s a nice thing to do.

‚ÄúEveryday we used to read. It started with just a chapter and then we’d read for an hour. Her reading skills are much better. She can read for herself now, but sometimes we still do go back to Harry Potter and we read a few chapters out loud because it’s a nice thing to do.‚Äù

Kate, TACT foster carer since 2017

Making a difference

Our young person came to us when she was 11. She couldn’t ride a bike and she couldn’t swim – although she liked to think she could. So we’d go out and we would do lots of ball catching games and we would take the bike out and do endless figures of eight – so she could get the hang of riding a bike and get her balance and all that. We facilitated swimming lessons and then we went and did lots of swimming as a family. Playing ball helped with her motor skills. Doing colouring and baking helped with her fine manipulative skills, and her hand eye coordination; that all helped when she started school.

We used to play board games after tea, and that helped her to focus and to understand turn taking and her understanding of rules.

It’s putting in place what she never got when she was little. It’s replacing those skills at a later date because they’re not instinctive. Now we’re seeing the fruition of what we put in place early on.

At least several times a week we sit down to dinner, we talk about our day – we talk about what’s important to us. Is there anything going on in our head that we might need to question or go through? The act of sitting down to dinner, the act of laying the table and eating together and preparing food together – and then the clearing away and taking turns and being in the same space at the same time; that act really, really changes things. It changes people because it brings everybody together. And it means that you do use the space together – the space of being a family. Some of these children weren’t given the opportunity to have a meal, let alone where they had the meal and who they had the meal with. But when you do that and you make that a normal thing, it starts changing the way the brain works – and that is the beginning of changing their lives.

You can make such a big difference to somebody’s life. My best advice to you is pick up the phone, click on that button and find out more. It will be the best thing you’ve ever done.

Watch Kate’s full video

Start Your Fostering Journey. Make An Extraordinary Difference.

items.title: Why I Want to Stay with My Foster Carers
items.snippet: Recently, a young person placed with Swiis Foster Carers, had the opportunity to share her wishes with the court. She wrote a touching letter about her current experience in foster care with her siblings and explained why she hopes she and her siblings remain long-term with their carers. The post Why I Want to Stay with My Foster Carers appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.
items.content:
When a child or young person comes into the care of the local authority, they are placed into a temporary home, which may be with foster carers in a short or long-term home-finding arrangement.

Recently, a young person placed with Swiis Foster Carers, had the opportunity to share her wishes with the court. She wrote a touching letter about her current experience in foster care with her siblings and explained why she hopes she and her siblings remain long-term with their carers.

This young person would like to selflessly share her letter with the hope that it will inspire others and show the incredible difference fostering can make in the life of a child or young person.

Names have been changed to protect the identity of the young person and foster carers. 

‚ÄúSarah and David are quite literally some of the sweetest people I have ever met. They have always been so caring and supportive since the very first day we arrived, and I have felt like I have already gotten more care and support from them in just a few months than I ever got with my mam in 15 years.¬†

I wasn‚Äôt very keen on them at the start as I felt like I didn‚Äôt fit in. They are social and I wasn‚Äôt, they liked going out to places, and I preferred staying at home. And I guess I wasn‚Äôt really used to the environment of a nice home and family dinners and showers/baths every night.

My first night, I cried loads. I missed my bed, and I felt like I made a very awful decision. But they made me feel so welcome. The first day, I had a nice relaxing bath, they gave me my space and let us get what we wanted for tea. And honestly, nothing has really changed since that day other than that we are more comfortable around each other, and I am so much happier now that I got the chance to be with such lovely people.

Ever since the first day, they have always been there for me, no matter what. They are always so caring and helpful. They are so supportive of everything I do. Every time I am upset, they always notice, and they are right on track to figure out what is wrong and try their best to help with the situation. And of course, if I want or need any space, they will respectfully give me some.

It‚Äôs not just them, the whole family are the most welcoming, caring and loving people anyone could ever ask for, and I feel like I warmed up to everyone quite fast. Living with them all has made me a better person.  

My mental health overall has been so much better than it was while I was with my mam. I have a healthier diet. Sarah and David make sure we are getting proper, nutritious food, instead of fries and chicken nuggets all the time. They also make sure everyone is okay with having that food for tea, and if someone isn‚Äôt, then normally small adjustments will be made. For example, when they make Curry, we aren‚Äôt that big on spice, so they make us a non-spicy ‚Äúcurry‚Äù. (By ‚Äúwe‚Äù, I am referring to me and my brothers). 

They always buy us things that we need, even if we don‚Äôt ask them to. Like one day it can just be brought up in a conversation, then a few days later it arrives. Obviously, they are responsible and try to teach us the value of money, so they don‚Äôt just buy us anything we want. If we want something that‚Äôs quite pricey or just a silly little thing, then we save up for it. If it is school related, or something crafty, just anything that would get us away from devices, or if its hygiene related, then they will buy it for us.

They are quite chill and relaxed and don‚Äôt let things people say bother them. They are constantly reminding me that people will just say things out of jealousy or boredom and that I should just ignore what people think or say about me. If they want to do that, then they can go ahead and do it. Why should it be my issue, I know I’m a good person.

Whenever I am stressed, they always try their best to help me out as much as they possibly can. There was a moment when I was constantly stressed in school, and it would cause me to scratch my skin. Sarah wasted no time getting me a fidget ring and bracelet to distract me, and she would give me some cream for my wounds.

Honestly, I have been such a better, happier and healthier person since living with them, and they have impacted my life in an amazing way. Even people at school have been saying that I look so much better than I used to.

I also have become a slightly more sociable, confident and productive person and I feel like I get more things done now. And I socialise with people a bit more since we are always going out. I have become more confident with myself, I used to be so insecure and now I don‚Äôt let that bother me as much. I‚Äôve even been doing more and better at subjects in school because I don‚Äôt have as much stress as I used to when living with my mam. I have been able to hand in my homework on time, get a lot of work done in lessons, and revise properly.  

They are the reason I am the person I am today.  

I feel like they would have an amazing impact on my future. I will actually have people to talk to about things like what to do when leaving school, how to find a job, how to deal with all sorts of payments, getting a house, college, and university. Just overall, how to be a good person.  

I feel like I will actually have someone to help me through any hard times I have, someone I can actually talk to about things. I am no longer afraid of growing up, because I know that I am surrounded by amazing people who will support me and be there for me through thick and thin. 

When I lived with my mam, I was constantly afraid of growing up. I wanted to be dead by the age of 16 just so that I didn‚Äôt need to live a life like my mams. 

Sarah and David have given me and my brothers such a safe environment to be in. They have given us the opportunities to experience different things and to explore more things, to figure out what we enjoy doing and what we don‚Äôt enjoy doing. They don‚Äôt let us give up, but they don‚Äôt force us either. They just give us a slight nudge to get us started, then let us continue the rest.  

They have made my life so much better in such a small amount of time, and I will forever be grateful to them and their whole family. I will always be grateful for everything they have done for us.  

Thank you so much for taking the time out of your day to read my letter. I really appreciate the chance to share a part of my story with you.  

Have an amazing day.

Sincerely ‚Äì N‚Äù

Has this letter inspired you to become a foster carer?

N has beautifully shown within this letter how much of an impact becoming a foster carer can have on a child or young person’s life. If this letter has inspired you to consider fostering and you would like to learn more, please contact our recruitment team. They will be happy to answer your questions and share details about the support and fostering allowance Swiis offers.

The post Why I Want to Stay with My Foster Carers appeared first on Swiis Foster Care.

items.title: Fostering When Your Own Child Has Additional Needs
items.snippet: If your child has additional needs, you might wonder how fostering will affect your family. This blog explores the key things to consider before fostering, how your child‚Äôs needs may influence your decision, and how fostering can still be a positive, rewarding experience for everyone involved‚Äîwith the right support. The post Fostering When Your Own Child Has Additional Needs appeared first on Orange Grove Foster Care.
items.content:
Choosing to foster is a huge decision for your family. If one of your own children has additional needs, you may be wondering how fostering might impact your family life.¬†¬†

Becoming a foster parent is incredibly rewarding, but it also has its challenges. Let‚Äôs take a look at some factors to consider if you‚Äôre thinking about fostering with children and how your own child‚Äôs needs will play a role in your decision.

Is fostering right for my own children?¬†

If you‚Äôre thinking about fostering while raising your own children, it‚Äôs really important to carefully and thoroughly consider if fostering is right for them. Having a child with additional needs does not mean that you‚Äôll be excluded from becoming a foster parent‚Äì in fact, your unique parenting experiences and knowledge might make you an ideal candidate to foster.¬†¬†

What really matters is if you‚Äôll have the capacity to care for your own needs, the needs of your children and the needs of the young people you‚Äôll foster all at the same time. Only you know your own limits and your child‚Äôs needs, and our team will be on hand during your fostering assessment process to help you decide if it‚Äôs the right time for your family to begin fostering.¬†¬†

¬†

How will fostering impact my own child?¬†¬†

Growing up in a foster family can be both a rewarding and at times complex lifestyle. Adjusting to a new sibling can be a challenge, especially if your child favours routine or isn‚Äôt used to sharing their time with you. Struggles with sibling jealousy may become a factor, there‚Äôs a chance that your child may begin to imitate the behaviours of their foster siblings, and it can also be very painful to say goodbye when it‚Äôs time for a foster sibling to move on.¬†¬†¬†

Having a foster sibling also has tons of benefits ‚Äì you may begin to see your child come out of their shell more as you help them to build a positive relationship with their new sibling, giving children the chance to build loving relationships which can last a lifetime. Growing up in a foster family can also help to teach skills such as sharing, empathy and compassion for others.¬†¬†

¬†

Which type of fostering is right for me?¬†

If you‚Äôre considering fostering while caring for a child with additional needs, one important factor to think about is which of the types of fostering will be best suited to your family‚Äôs needs.¬†¬†

For example, if your own child has autism, they may thrive better while living with a long-term foster sibling who will stay with the family until they reach adulthood rather than a style of fostering which involves many different children coming to live with you, such as respite or emergency fostering.¬†¬†

¬†

Do I have capacity to foster a child?¬†¬†

If your child has any additional needs, such as a physical disability, a neurological condition like Autism or ADHD, a learning disability or mental health struggles, you likely dedicate lots of time, energy and compassion to supporting them day-to-day.¬†¬†

Children who come into care also tend to need extra care and support. Many children in care live with complex developmental trauma as a result of their experiences at home, which can include abuse and neglect. As a foster parent, you‚Äôll also take on lots of additional responsibilities to support your foster child‚Äôs wellbeing, such as attending frequent meetings, taking children to visit their birth family and completing daily paperwork. Be sure to carefully consider if you have the capacity to fully meet the needs of both your own children and the children who you‚Äôll foster.¬†¬†

¬†

The importance of self-care for foster parents¬†

Selflessness and putting the needs of children above your own are just some of the qualities which make a fantastic foster parent. However, only by giving proper care and attention to your own mental health will you be able to give your best to all of the children in your care.¬†¬†

As we discussed above, fostering a child comes with a lot of additional responsibilities, and you need to be sure that you can balance everybody‚Äôs needs while fostering, including your own. You must be able to trust that you‚Äôll have enough time and energy to manage all of your caring responsibilities without becoming burned out. Check out our self-care guide for foster parents to learn more about finding balance as a foster parent.¬†¬†

Could you foster a child with additional needs?¬†

Each foster parent has unique strengths and experiences which they bring to their role. If you are already experienced in caring for a child with additional needs, this could make you the ideal candidate to specialise in fostering children with complex needs.¬†¬†

With a current shortage of foster parents who are able to accommodate the needs of children with disabilities, your rich experience and support could be invaluable in changing a child‚Äôs life.¬†¬†

items.title: Quad-tastic Event For Our North East Young People
items.snippet: TACT Yorkshire & North East took six of our young people quad biking - something that they had never experienced before! The post Quad-tastic Event For Our North East Young People appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
Quad-tastic Event For Our North East Young People

  • Home
  • News

TACT Yorkshire and North East were recently awarded a donation of ¬£1333 from the John Lewis Community Matters Scheme, which funded a trip to Mission Out in Leeds.

As there were funds left over from this event, we consulted with our young people to find out what they would like to do as another activity. The vote for quad biking, which none of them had done before, was pretty unanimous!

We took six of our young people to Yorkshire Outdoors, who kindly gave us a charity discount, where they got to try quad biking for an hour. The Yorkshire Outdoors staff were amazing with our young people, and kept them safe at all times.

It did get rather wet at times, but everyone really enjoyed biking around the track in the rain!

All our young people had a great time, and it was wonderful to witness them socialising and nurturing friendships made from previous social trips and events. We even managed to talk with them about our Connect community, which they are able to join upon turning 15. All were very excited to sign up.

When we spoke to our young people about the event, they all thoroughly enjoyed it, but it was the social aspect that they really appreciated:

‚ÄúI can see other children my age. The event was really good, I get to be myself, and I get to see [other] people in care, so I feel included.‚Äù

‚ÄúI get to make lots of new mates and have fun at the same time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel happy ‚Äì it makes a difference in my life because I get to see my mates.‚Äù

Bringing our young people together for activities such as this is invaluable from a social point of view. Here at TACT we run multiple events, which means our children get to make new friends, and reconnect with more established friendships that they have previously made.

A big thank you to John Lewis and our Yorkshire and North East staff for enabling this wonderful event!

The post Quad-tastic Event For Our North East Young People appeared first on TACT.

items.title: Advocating For Our Children‚Äôs Educational Future
items.snippet: TACT advocated for the Special Educational Needs (SEN) of one of our young people. Read what happened, and why advocacy is so important. The post Advocating For Our Children‚Äôs Educational Future appeared first on TACT.
items.content:
Advocating For Our Children‚Äôs Educational Future

  • Home
  • Articles
  • Advocating For Our Children‚Äôs Educational Future

As the UK‚Äôs largest dedicated fostering charity, TACT have always advocated for young people, and lobbied for change at a governmental level. Andy Elvin, TACT‚Äôs CEO and Chair of the Fairer Fostering Partnership, has always been a visual presence in the media, showing that it‚Äôs one thing to say that you advocate for children, but it‚Äôs another thing to actually do it. Recently, our Education Service supported a young person to appeal a decision made by a local authority about whether they had Special Educational Needs (SEN) and required an Individual Development Plan moving forward. 

Our young person, who has been with her foster carers for 12 years, finished her GCSE‚Äôs this year (2025). Although she received additional support whilst at primary school, for some reason this ceased when she started secondary school ‚Äì despite the fact that she still required this support.

With challenges that included struggling to read, telling the time and numeracy, her foster carers were concerned for her future. Along with our team, they had been pushing to get additional educational support for her for a while. That‚Äôs when our Education Service stepped in to help. 

From Appeal To Tribunal

When appeal and mediation efforts were unsuccessful, our Head of Education advocated on behalf of our young person and the case was taken to a tribunal.  

Thorough preparation was critical and was a real team effort between our Education Service, Supervising Social Worker and foster carers.  As a team, they were able to evidence and demonstrate that our young person met the legal criteria for having additional learning needs. 

The tribunal process, which involved looking at reports and additional information from teachers, social workers, an Educational Psychologist and other professionals, proved that our young person had learning difficulties requiring educational support on a day-to-day basis. It was then agreed that her Individual Development Plan should be reviewed when transitioning into college.

The importance of educational advocation

Our Education Service strives to improve the educational experiences of our children and young people. The service not only provides advice, but will attend meetings such as PEPs (Personal Education Plans) or reviews where there are educational concerns.

Should any further action be required, such as an Additional Learning Needs appeal, our Education Service can act as a case representative. 

Advocation can achieve real results, and can change a young person‚Äôs educational landscape for the better. It is highly important that we continue to advocate for children and young people on an individual and national level to raise issues and drive solutions.  

Read more about our Education Service.
